column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute respiratory distress and confusion. He has a history of Sanfilippo syndrome type C, a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and causes progressive intellectual decline. On examination, he is lethargic and unresponsive, with a weak cough and decreased breath sounds on the right side of his chest. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. He has a history of recurrent respiratory infections and has been non-verbal since his early twenties. Family members report that he has had increasing difficulty with ambulation and has become more dependent on caregivers for daily activities over the past year.
column17: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his concerned parents, who report that their son has been experiencing difficulty sleeping and has become increasingly aggressive over the past year. The child also displays hyperkinesia and has recently developed a tendency to repeat words and phrases. On physical examination, the boy appears healthy, but his speech is delayed, and he demonstrates mild cognitive impairment during play-based assessments. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Sanfilippo syndrome type C (MPS III-C), a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme NAGLU. The parents are counseled about the progressive nature of the disease and its impact on their child's cognitive, behavioral, and physical development. They are also informed about the availability of clinical trials for investigational therapies and the importance of early intervention to minimize disease progression.
column24:
A 35-year-old woman with Sanfilippo syndrome type C presents to the clinic with her caregiver. She has a history of developmental delay, intellectual disability, and autism spectrum disorder. She has been experiencing increasing difficulty with communication, memory loss, and confusion over the past year. She has also developed seizures and sleep disturbances. On examination, she has a distinctive facial appearance with coarse features, a large head, and a flat nasal bridge. Her speech is limited to a few words, and she has difficulty walking due to muscle stiffness and contractures. She also has hearing loss and vision problems. The patient's caregiver reports that she has become increasingly aggressive and irritable in recent months. The patient's neurological symptoms have rapidly progressed over the past year, and her caregiver is concerned about her declining quality of life.

The most important clinical features of this patient's presentation are:

* Developmental delay and intellectual disability
* Autism spectrum disorder
* Progressive neurological symptoms including memory loss, confusion, seizures, and sleep disturbances
* Distinctive facial appearance with coarse features
* Muscle stiffness and contractures
* Hearing loss and vision problems

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of blurred vision in both eyes. He has a family history of X-linked retinoschisis, and his mother was diagnosed with the condition when she was a child. On examination, visual acuity is 20/50 in each eye, and there is a notable nasal step in the visual acuity chart. Funduscopic examination reveals bilateral retinoschisis, with a "snowflake" pattern of small, round, and oval-shaped exudates in the peripheral retina. The patient also has a left esotropia. Fluorescein angiography shows early hyperfluorescence in the peripheral retina, indicating leakage from the retinal vessels. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of X-linked retinoschisis.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the eye clinic with a complaint of blurred vision in both eyes that has been gradually worsening over the past few years. He also reports difficulty seeing at night and experiencing flashes of light in his peripheral vision. On examination, visual acuity is 20/50 in each eye, with a right-left asymmetry. Funduscopic examination reveals a characteristic "snowflake" pattern of retinal degeneration in both eyes, with areas of retinoschisis and atrophy. The patient has a positive family history of X-linked retinoschisis, with several affected male relatives. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis.
column17: A 7-year-old boy presents to the pediatric ophthalmology clinic with complaints of blurry vision and difficulty reading. He has had these symptoms since he was 4 years old, but they have been gradually worsening over time. On examination, his visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes, and funduscopic examination reveals areas of schisis in the macula of both eyes, giving a spoke wheel pattern appearance. The patient's mother mentions that her brother also had similar vision problems when he was young. The patient is diagnosed with X-linked retinoschisis, and genetic testing confirms the presence of the RS1 mutation. Further management includes close monitoring of the patient's vision, glasses or contact lenses to correct refractive errors, and early detection and treatment of any complications such as retinal detachment or glaucoma. The family is also counseled regarding the X-linked inheritance pattern and the risk of recurrence in future offspring.
column24:
A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of blurry vision and difficulty reading small print. He reports that he has had trouble seeing since childhood but never sought treatment. On examination, visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals areas of schisis in the macula of both eyes, with a spoke wheel pattern visible. There is no evidence of retinal detachment or vitreous hemorrhage. The patient is diagnosed with X-linked retinoschisis and referred for genetic counseling to determine if any family members are at risk.
The most important clinical features in this vignette are:
Symmetrical bilateral macular involvement
Onset in the first decade of life
Areas of schisis (splitting of the nerve fiber layer of the retina) in the macula
Spoke wheel pattern visible on fundus examination
No evidence of retinal detachment or vitreous hemorrhage.

column1: Hemolytic anemia due to red cell pyruvate kinase deficiency
column3:
A 4-year-old boy presents with a history of fatigue, jaundice, and pallor. He has had recurrent episodes of fever, headache, and vomiting over the past year. On examination, he has a pale, jaundiced complexion, and his vital signs are normal. There is no splenomegaly or lymphadenopathy. His complete blood count shows a hemoglobin of 7 g/dL, reticulocyte count of 12%, and a positive direct Coombs test. A diagnosis of hemolytic anemia due to red cell pyruvate kinase deficiency is suspected. The most important clinical features are:
Fatigue
Jaundice
Pallor
Recurrent episodes of fever, headache, and vomiting
Low hemoglobin and reticulocyte count
Positive direct Coombs test
No splenomegaly or lymphadenopathy.
column10:
A 35-year-old male presents with fatigue, jaundice, shortness of breath, and a history of recurrent episodes of anemia, splenomegaly, and petechiae. He has a family history of similar symptoms in his siblings. Physical examination reveals a spleen tip that is 4 cm below the costal margin, and there are signs of moderate anemia, including pallor, conjunctival pallor, and a low blood pressure. The patient's reticulocyte count is high, and direct Coombs test is negative. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the PKLR gene, consistent with red cell pyruvate kinase deficiency.
The most important clinical features of this case are:
1. Recurrent episodes of anemia, splenomegaly, and petechiae
2. Family history of similar symptoms
3. High reticulocyte count
4. Negative direct Coombs test
5. Mutation in the PKLR gene
column17: A 3-year-old boy presents with a history of jaundice since birth, and recurrent episodes of fever, fatigue, and vomiting. He has had multiple blood transfusions in the past year. Physical examination reveals icteric sclera, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests show hemoglobin 7 g/dL, reticulocyte count 15%, and direct Coombs test positive. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of red cell pyruvate kinase deficiency. The most important clinical features in this case are neonatal jaundice, recurrent episodes of fever and fatigue, splenomegaly, and positive direct Coombs test.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of recurrent episodes of fatigue, jaundice, and dark urine over the past year. She also reports experiencing frequent infections and abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals icterus, splenomegaly, and mild anemia. Laboratory tests show a low red blood cell count, reticulocytosis, and elevated indirect bilirubin. A diagnosis of hemolytic anemia due to red cell pyruvate kinase deficiency is suspected based on the patient's clinical features and laboratory results. Further genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The most important clinical features in this case are recurrent episodes of fatigue, jaundice, dark urine, frequent infections, abdominal pain, icterus, splenomegaly, low red blood cell count, reticulocytosis, and elevated indirect bilirubin.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a history of recurrent fractures and bone pain. He has a family history of similar symptoms in his siblings. On examination, he has short stature, large head, and prominent forehead. His skin is thin and fragile, and there are multiple healing fractures on his arms and legs. X-rays reveal diffuse osteoporosis and thickening of the skull and long bones. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Albers-Schönberg osteopetrosis.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of recurrent fractures and bone pain. She has a family history of similar symptoms in her mother and grandmother. On examination, she has a short stature, with a height of 140 cm, and has a characteristic "coarse" facial appearance, with prominent forehead, nasal bridge, and jaw. Her skin is thickened and there are multiple healed fractures on her arms and legs. She has a history of easy bruising and bleeding. Laboratory tests show low serum levels of vitamin D and high levels of alkaline phosphatase. A radiograph of the skull shows evidence of osteopetrosis, with increased bone density and "bone-within-bone" appearance. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the TCIRG1 gene, consistent with Albers-Schönberg osteopetrosis.
column17: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after falling from a bike and fracturing his left humerus. He has a history of multiple previous fractures, including a right humeral fracture 3 years ago, a left femoral fracture 2 years ago, and a right tibial fracture 1 year ago. His parents also mention that he has had recurrent dental abscesses and caries. On examination, the patient has short stature, with a height of 4 feet 8 inches (56 inches) and a weight of 70 pounds (32 kg). He has mild scoliosis and limited mobility in his left arm due to the recent fracture. His vision and hearing are normal. The patient is diagnosed with Albers-Schönberg osteopetrosis based on clinical, radiographic, and genetic testing findings.
column24: A 30-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of recurrent fractures and bone pain. She has had multiple fractures in her long bones, including her femurs, tibias, and humeri, as well as her spine and ribs. She also reports experiencing chronic lower back pain and scoliosis. The patient has a history of dental problems, including recurrent abscesses and caries. On examination, she has evidence of osteoporosis, with a prominent forehead, thinning of the skin, and a small jaw. She also has hearing loss and blurred vision. The patient is diagnosed with Albers-Schönberg osteopetrosis based on her clinical features, radiographs, and genetic testing.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3:
A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with vomiting, abdominal pain, and seizures after ingesting fruit snacks containing fructose. He has a history of similar episodes following consumption of fruits or sweets. Physical examination reveals signs of dehydration, tachycardia, and lethargy. Laboratory tests show elevated blood fructose levels and low activity of the enzyme aldolase B. The patient is diagnosed with hereditary fructose intolerance, a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of aldolase B.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
1. Seizures and vomiting following consumption of fructose-containing foods
2. History of similar episodes
3. Elevated blood fructose levels
4. Low activity of the enzyme aldolase B
5. Diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, vomiting and diarrhea after eating a meal containing fruits and milk. He has a history of similar episodes since childhood. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the abdomen, but no signs of peritonitis. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of fructose in the blood and urine. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance.
The most important clinical features for this scenario are:
* Severe abdominal pain
* Vomiting and diarrhea
* History of similar episodes since childhood
* Elevated levels of fructose in the blood and urine
* Confirmation of diagnosis through genetic testing.
column17: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his parents after experiencing recurrent vomiting, abdominal pain and lethargy following consumption of fruit juice and candy. The patient has a history of failure to thrive and developmental delay. Physical examination reveals hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, ketosis and hepatomegaly. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of uric acid, alanine and aspartate transaminases. The patient is diagnosed with hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) and is put on a strict fructose-free diet. With appropriate dietary management, the patient experiences resolution of symptoms and normalization of laboratory values.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a lifelong history of avoiding fruits and sweets, recurrent vomiting, abdominal pain, and hypoglycemia following consumption of fructose-containing foods. She also reports growth retardation during childhood and a history of seizures. Physical examination reveals a thin built, prominent abdomen, and mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory tests show hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hypophosphatemia. The patient is diagnosed with hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI), and a genetic test confirms the presence of a mutation in the aldolase B gene. She is advised to follow a strict fructose-free diet, which leads to significant improvement in symptoms and normalization of laboratory values. The patient is also referred for nutritional counseling to ensure adequate intake of essential nutrients while avoiding fructose-containing foods.

column3:
A 10-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office with a history of joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and recurrent joint dislocations. She has a positive family history of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and her mother has the same condition. On examination, she has loose skin, and her joints demonstrate increased range of motion. The patient also reports experiencing chronic pain and fatigue.
The most important clinical features for this patient with Classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome include:
* Joint hypermobility (increased range of motion)
* Skin hyperextensibility (loose skin)
* Recurrent joint dislocations
* Positive family history of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
* Chronic pain and fatigue.
column10:
A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and recurrent joint dislocations. She has had multiple surgeries for shoulder, knee, and ankle instability and has difficulty with daily activities such as walking and dressing due to joint pain and weakness. Family history reveals a similar condition in her mother and maternal grandmother. Physical examination shows markedly lax skin and joints, with easy bruising and poor wound healing. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS).
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
1. Joint hypermobility
2. Skin hyperextensibility
3. Recurrent joint dislocations
4. Family history of similar condition
5. Markedly lax skin and joints
6. Easy bruising
7. Poor wound healing
8. Genetic testing confirming the diagnosis of Classical EDS.
column17: A 6-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office with her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's excessive bruising and skin fragility. The patient has a history of easy bruising since early childhood, and her mother reports that she has been experiencing joint pain and frequent dislocations of her shoulders and knees. On physical examination, the patient's skin appears soft, velvety, and doughy to the touch. She has multiple atrophic scars on her arms and legs, which are thin and stretched out. Her joints are hypermobile, and she experiences pain and discomfort during movement. The patient also has a history of delayed motor development and muscle fatigue. Her facial features show blepharochalasis and epicanthal folds. The patient is diagnosed with Classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (cEDS), and the mother is counseled about the need for close monitoring and management of her daughter's symptoms to prevent further complications.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician's office, seeking medical advice for her long history of joint dislocations and skin problems. She has had recurrent subluxations of her shoulders and patellas since she was a teenager, and has experienced multiple episodes of skin tears and bruising following minor trauma. She also mentions that it takes longer than usual for her wounds to heal. On physical examination, the patient's skin is soft, velvety, and hyperextensible, with atrophic scarring noted on her arms and legs. Her joints demonstrate a Beighton score of six, indicating generalized joint hypermobility. The patient also reports muscle fatigue and cramping, which has led to delayed motor development in the past. She is diagnosed with Classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (cEDS) based on her clinical features and genetic testing results, which reveal a mutation in the COL1A1 gene. The patient is referred to a multidisciplinary team of specialists for further management and counseling.

column3:
A 7-year-old boy, John, presents to the pediatrician with a history of persistent cough and difficulty breathing. He was born prematurely at 32 weeks and has had recurrent respiratory infections since infancy. His parents have noticed that he gets tired easily when playing and often has a nasal voice. On examination, John's vital signs are normal, but his chest examination reveals a prolonged expiratory phase, and his nasal mucus is thick and sticky. The patient's height and weight are below the 25th percentile for his age.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
1. Persistent cough and difficulty breathing
2. Premature birth
3. Recurrent respiratory infections since infancy
4. Prolonged expiratory phase on chest examination
5. Thick and sticky nasal mucus
6. Below-average height and weight for age.
column10: A 35-year-old woman comes to your office with a long history of chronic cough, which has been getting worse over the past year. She also reports recurrent respiratory infections and difficulty breathing. On examination, her vital signs are normal, but she has a prolonged expiratory phase and wheezing on lung auscultation. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the chest reveals bilateral bronchiectasis with cystic changes. Genetic testing reveals primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD).
column17: A 3-month-old male infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to concerns of difficulty breathing and frequent coughing episodes. The baby was born at full term without any complications but has had recurrent respiratory issues since birth, requiring supplemental oxygen intermittently. He has a history of daily rhinitis and wet cough, and his parents report that he often chokes or gags during feedings. Physical examination reveals tachypnea, nasal flaring, and intercostal retractions. The patient is diagnosed with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a genetic disorder affecting the structure and function of cilia, which are tiny hair-like structures found in the respiratory tract that help to clear mucus and debris from the lungs. The most important clinical features of PCD include neonatal respiratory distress, chronic wet cough, recurrent lower airway infections, and bronchiectasis. In this case, the patient's symptoms began shortly after birth, indicating that PCD can present early in life. The diagnosis is confirmed with a sweat test or genetic testing.
column24: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a history of recurrent respiratory infections, chronic cough, and difficulty breathing. He reports that he has had these symptoms since childhood but they have worsened over the past year. The patient also mentions that he has had multiple sinus infections and has noticed some hearing loss recently. On physical examination, the patient appears thin and has a prominent nasal bridge. His lung sounds are diminished on the right side, and there is a high-pitched expiratory wheeze audible over the trachea. The patient's sputum production is purulent, and he has a history of recurrent pneumonia. The patient is diagnosed with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a genetic disorder that affects the structure and function of cilia, leading to respiratory problems. The most important clinical features in this case include the patient's history of recurrent respiratory infections, chronic cough, hearing loss, and physical examination findings such as diminished lung sounds and purulent sputum production. These symptoms are consistent with PCD, which can lead to bronchiectasis, chronic infections, and other respiratory complications if left untreated.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3:
A 3-year-old boy named Max presents to the clinic with his parents due to concerns about his growth and development. He was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a birth weight of 2.5 kg. His parents are both of average height (168 cm and 170 cm, respectively). Max's height is currently 70 cm, which is below the 10th percentile for his age. He also has a large head, short arms and legs, and a prominent forehead. Max's developmental milestones have been delayed, and he is currently unable to walk independently. His limbs are also very weak, and he has difficulty grasping objects with his hands.
The most important clinical features of this patient vignette are:
1. Short stature: Max's height is below the 10th percentile for his age, which indicates short stature.
2. Large head: Max has a large head, which is a characteristic feature of Achondroplasia.
3. Short arms and legs: Max's arms and legs are short in proportion to his body, which is another feature of Achondroplasia.
4. Prominent forehead: Max has a prominent forehead, which is also a feature of Achondroplasia.
5. Delayed developmental milestones
column10: A 35-year-old man named Jack presents to the office with a chief complaint of back pain. He was diagnosed with achondroplasia at birth and has been followed by a multidisciplinary team throughout his life. Despite this, he has had increasing difficulty ambulating in recent years and now relies on a wheelchair for mobility. His back pain is located in the lower back and radiates to his right leg. He also reports decreased sensation in his legs and feet. On examination, Jack's stature is 4 feet, with a large head, short arms and legs, and normal-appearing torso. His gait is waddling, and he has marked lumbar lordosis. Neurological examination reveals decreased sensation to light touch in the L2-S1 dermatomes. Imaging studies show multilevel degenerative disc disease and spinal stenosis.
column17: A 3-year-old boy named Max presents to the clinic with his parents, who are concerned about his slow development and short stature. Max was born at term and had a normal birth weight, but since then, his growth has been slower than expected. He is currently 70 cm tall and weighs 12 kg, which puts him below the 5th percentile for both height and weight. On examination, the physician notes that Max's limbs are short and thin, with a rhizomelic pattern of shortening. His head is large and long, with frontal bossing and midface retrusion. Max has difficulty standing and walking independently due to his short legs and hypotonia. He also has a prominent forehead and a depressed nasal bridge. The physician suspects that Max may have Achondroplasia, a genetic disorder that affects the development of cartilage and bone, leading to short stature and characteristic facial features. To confirm the diagnosis, the physician orders an X-ray of Max's spine and limbs, as well as genetic testing to identify any mutations in the genes associated with Achondroplasia.
column24:
A 35-year-old man with achondroplasia presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up appointment. He is accompanied by his wife, who is also affected by the condition. The patient reports experiencing increasing fatigue and shortness of breath over the past year, which he attributes to his difficulty in walking long distances due to his short stature and kyphosis. On examination, the patient's height is 125 cm, and he has a large head, broad and short hands, and a trident-shaped hand. His neck is short, and he has a prominent forehead and midface hypoplasia. The patient's thoracolumbar spine shows evidence of past kyphosis, which has resolved over time. He also has mild obstructive sleep apnea and conductive hearing loss due to chronic otitis media. The patient is concerned about his recent symptoms and asks for advice on how to manage them.
The most important clinical features of this patient's presentation are:

* Short stature (125 cm)
* Large head
* Broad and short hands with a trident shape
* Short neck
* Prominent forehead and midface hypoplasia
* Evidence of past thoracolumbar kyphosis
* Mild obstructive sleep apnea

column3: A 12-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a 6-month history of progressive visual loss in both eyes. He has difficulty seeing objects clearly and often bumps into things. His medical history is unremarkable, but his maternal grandfather was diagnosed with similar symptoms at the same age. On examination, his best-corrected visual acuity is 20/400 in each eye, and funduscopic examination reveals bilateral optic disc pallor. Visual field testing shows a central scotoma in both eyes. The patient is diagnosed with Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON), a rare genetic disorder that affects the mitochondria in the retinal ganglion cells, leading to progressive loss of central vision.
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden vision loss in his right eye. He has a history of similar episodes in the past, but they have always resolved on their own. This time, however, the vision loss persists, and he notices that his left eye is also affected. On examination, visual acuity is 20/200 in the right eye and 20/400 in the left eye. Funduscopic examination reveals bilateral optic disc edema. The patient has a family history of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, and genetic testing confirms the diagnosis.
Important clinical features:
Sudden vision loss
Recurrent episodes of vision loss in the past
Bilateral optic disc edema
Family history of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
Positive genetic testing for LHON
column17: A 19-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden, painless vision loss in both eyes over the past week. He reports difficulty reading and recognizing faces, and has noticed a gradual worsening of his central vision over the past few months. He denies any eye pain or discomfort, and has no history of eye trauma or previous visual problems. On examination, his best-corrected visual acuity is 20/80 in both eyes, with a central scotoma (blind spot) in the center of his visual field. He has normal peripheral vision and color perception. Funduscopic examination reveals a bilateral papilledema (swelling of the optic disc). The patient is referred to a neurologist for further evaluation, and genetic testing reveals a positive mutation in the mtDNA LHON gene.
column24: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden, painless vision loss in both eyes over the past week. He reports difficulty reading and recognizing faces, and notes that his central vision has been gradually worsening over the past few months. On examination, visual acuity is 20/400 in both eyes, with a central scotoma. Funduscopic examination reveals bilateral optic disc edema. The patient has no other neurological symptoms. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON).

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, vomiting, and lethargy. He has a history of recurrent episodes of fever and vomiting, and his parents report that he often has a "sour smell" to his sweat and urine. On examination, the patient appears ill and dehydrated, with a temperature of 102°F (39°C). He has a mild cough and tender abdomen, but no signs of meningism or focal neurological deficits. Laboratory tests reveal a normal complete blood count and electrolyte panel, but an elevated urinary amino acid concentration. The patient is diagnosed with Hartnup disease, a rare genetic disorder caused by a defect in the tryptophan transport system. Treatment includes supportive care for dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, as well as dietary restrictions to limit tryptophan intake.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a 6-month history of intermittent vomiting, diarrhea, and weight loss. He reports that he often has a sour or bitter taste in his mouth and that his sense of smell is heightened. He also mentions that he has had recurrent episodes of confusion, disorientation, and difficulty concentrating. The patient appears thin and gaunt, with a prominent occipital protuberance. His blood work reveals a normocytic anemia, hypokalemia, and metabolic acidosis.
column17: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his mother, who reports that her son has been experiencing intermittent episodes of skin rashes, cerebellar ataxia, and neurological symptoms over the past year. The child's medical history is unremarkable, and he has been developing normally. However, his mother mentions that he has been more sensitive to sunlight recently, and the symptoms seem to worsen during the spring and summer months. On physical examination, the boy appears healthy, with no signs of pallor or jaundice. His skin is smooth and dry, without any evidence of a rash. He has full range of motion in all his joints, but his gait is mildly ataxic. There is no nystagmus or strabismus. The boy's speech is clear, and he appears to understand and respond appropriately to questions. His reflexes are normal, without any signs of hyperreflexia. The results of a complete blood count, electrolyte panel, and liver function tests are within normal limits. A urine organic acid analysis reveals an increased excretion of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of intermittent cerebellar ataxia, spasticity, trembling, and headaches that worsen in the spring and summer months. She also reports experiencing anxiety, emotional instability, delusions, and hallucinations during these times. The patient has a history of skin photosensitivity and has noticed that her symptoms tend to flare up after sunlight exposure. She has tried various medications and therapies without much relief. On examination, the patient appears disheveled and agitated, with difficulty walking due to ataxia. Her speech is slurred, and she experiences tremors in her upper extremities. The patient's skin exhibits a pellagra-like rash on her face and arms. The physician suspects Hartnup disease based on the patient's symptoms and medical history and orders further diagnostic tests to confirm the diagnosis.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever. He has a history of recurrent respiratory infections and was recently diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, and a mass is felt in the same area. The patient is admitted for further evaluation and management.
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He has a history of recurrent kidney stones and has been diagnosed with Meckel syndrome. On examination, his blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg, heart rate 120 beats per minute, respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute, and temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F). Abdominal examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the right flank, with guarding and rebound tenderness. The patient is diaphoretic and appears uncomfortable. Urinalysis shows pyuria and hematuria.
Important clinical features:
Severe abdominal pain
History of recurrent kidney stones
Meckel syndrome diagnosis
Elevated blood pressure
Tenderness to palpation over the right flank
Guarding and rebound tenderness
Pyuria and hematuria on urinalysis
column17: A 3-month-old boy presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing and fever. He was born at 34 weeks gestation via emergency cesarean section due to fetal distress. His birth weight was low (1.2 kg), and he required oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation in the neonatal intensive care unit. Physical examination reveals a small child with a prominent occipital encephalocele, micrognathia, and cleft palate. His limbs are short and show postaxial polydactyly of both hands. The abdomen is distended, and the kidneys feel large to the examiner. There is a cardiac murmur. The child is developmentally delayed, and his eyes show signs of microphthalmia. Family history reveals that the parents are consanguineous and have two other children who died in infancy from similar symptoms.
column24:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of shortness of breath and fatigue. She has a history of recurrent respiratory infections and was born with polydactyly (an extra finger on each hand). Physical examination reveals a small head size, prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, short nose, and a thin upper lip. The patient has a soft, high-pitched voice and a small jaw. She also has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and kidney stones. Abdominal examination reveals an enlarged liver and kidneys. Imaging studies show holoprosencephaly (a single, large brain hemisphere), hydrocephalus (fluid accumulation in the brain), and Dandy-Walker syndrome (a congenital brain malformation). The patient is diagnosed with Meckel syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of multiple organs and systems. The most important clinical features of this case include:

* Polydactyly (extra fingers)
* Short stature
* Distinctive facial features (prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, short nose, thin upper lip)
* Respiratory problems (shortness of breath, recurrent respiratory infections)

column3: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents due to delayed pubertal development and short stature. He has always had a small appetite and eats very little, but he drinks plenty of water. His height is below the third percentile for his age, and he has not yet entered puberty. He has a normal intelligence quotient (IQ) and no other dysmorphic features. Physical examination reveals a small, undescended testis on the right side, and the left testis is not palpable. The patient's voice is high-pitched, and he has a mild cognitive delay. Family history is unremarkable.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of infertility and lack of interest in sex. He also mentions that he has had difficulty smelling certain odors, such as the scent of flowers or food, for many years. On physical examination, the patient is found to have a number of dysmorphic features, including a small jaw, widely spaced eyes, and a flat nasal bridge. Genetic testing reveals that he has Kallmann syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the reproductive system and olfactory system. The patient is referred to a specialist for further evaluation and management of his condition.
column17: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the endocrinology clinic by his parents due to lack of pubertal development. He has always had a small penis and undescended testes, and his height and weight have been below the 25th percentile for his age. He also reports difficulty smelling odors. On examination, he has no breast tissue, sparse body hair, and decreased bone density. His testicular volume is less than 4 mL. The patient's sense of smell is impaired, and he has a history of frequent respiratory infections. The patient is diagnosed with Kallmann syndrome, and hormone replacement therapy is initiated to promote pubertal development and improve his bone density.
column24: A 27-year-old male presents to the endocrinology clinic with a history of delayed puberty and anosmia (lack of sense of smell). He reports that he has never had a spontaneous erection or ejaculation, and that his libido is low. He also mentions that he has always had difficulty hearing and has worn hearing aids since childhood. Physical examination reveals a tall, thin man with decreased facial and body hair, small testes, and a soft, flaccid penis. His bone density is low, and he has a history of fractures. The patient is diagnosed with Kallmann syndrome, and further testing reveals a mutation in the KAL1 gene. Treatment options, including hormone replacement therapy and assisted reproductive technology, are discussed with the patient.

column3: A 3-year-old boy, John, presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother due to concerns about his growth and development. John was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a birth weight of 2.8 kg. His mother reports that he has always been small for his age and has struggled to gain weight. On examination, John's height is below the 10th percentile, and his weight is below the 5th percentile. He has a small head circumference and a short arm span. John also has mild intellectual disability and delayed speech development. His physical examination reveals a number of dysmorphic features, including a flat nasal bridge, a small jaw, and widely spaced eyes. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of short stature, intellectual disability, and distinctive facial features, including a flat nasal bridge, a small jaw, and widely spaced eyes. She also has a history of seizures and poor coordination. The patient is diagnosed with Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme 7-dehydrocholesterol reductase. The most important clinical features of this condition include the distinctive facial features, intellectual disability, seizures, and short stature.
column17: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office for a routine checkup. His parents express concern about his speech and language development, as well as his difficulty paying attention and following instructions. The child also has a history of poor feeding and gastroesophageal reflux. On physical examination, the patient is found to have microcephaly, bitemporal narrowing, ptosis, broad nasal bridge, short nasal root, anteverted nares, small chin, and micrognathia. He also has postaxial polydactyly of the hands and feet, syndactyly of the 2nd and 3rd toes, and short and proximally placed thumbs. The patient is diagnosed with Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome based on his clinical features and laboratory tests showing a deficiency in 7-dehydrocholesterol (7-DHC) reductase enzyme activity. Further evaluation reveals a ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, and atrioventricular canal, as well as a cleft palate and gastrointestinal anomalies. The patient is referred to a multidisciplinary team for further management and follow-up.
column24: A 27-year-old male presents to the clinic with his caregiver due to concerns of worsening behavioral problems over the past year. He was diagnosed with Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome at birth and has been followed by a multidisciplinary team since then. His growth has been stable, but he has had difficulty gaining weight. He has moderate intellectual disability and has been working with a special education teacher since childhood. He has a broad nasal bridge, short nasal root, anteverted nares, small chin, micrognathia, bitemporal narrowing, ptosis, and strabismus. He has a history of sleep disturbances and hyperactivity. He has a small penis, hypospadias, and ambiguous genitalia. His cardiovascular exam reveals an atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, and patent ductus arteriosus. His abdominal exam shows a pyloric stenosis. He has postaxial polydactyly of the hands and feet and short and proximally placed thumbs. The patient is very photosensitive and has difficulty tolerating bright lights. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux and poor feeding as an infant. His developmental delays have resulted in social isolation.

column3: A 6-month-old girl, Sarah, is brought to the pediatrician's office by her parents due to concerns about her development. She was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a low birth weight of 2.4 kg. Her parents mention that she has been having difficulty feeding and has not been gaining weight as expected. On examination, Sarah appears small for her age and has a distinctive facial appearance with a flat nasal bridge, thin upper lip, and widely spaced eyes. She also has a single crease in the palm of her hand. The pediatrician suspects Trisomy 13 and orders a chromosomal analysis to confirm the diagnosis.
column10: A 25-year-old woman gives birth to a baby girl at 37 weeks gestation. The baby weighs 2.4 kg and is 48 cm long. On physical examination, the baby has a flat nasal bridge, small ears, and a short neck. The baby also has a single crease in her palm and a simian crease on her left hand. The baby's limbs are weak and she has difficulty moving them. The baby is also having trouble breathing and is making grunting noises while breathing.
column17: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the emergency room due to seizures and decreased responsiveness. She was born at 34 weeks of gestation, weighing 1.5 kg (3.3 lbs), with Apgar scores of 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Her growth parameters have been below the third percentile since birth. Physical examination shows a small child with a large head, short limbs, and facial dysmorphism consisting of hypotelorism, premaxillary agenesis, and microphthalmia. The child is lethargic, with poor reactivity to stimuli and minimal spontaneous movements. There is a grade II/VI holosystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border. Abdominal examination reveals a soft, non-tender liver edge palpable 2 cm below the costal margin. The child's temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 15 x 10(9)/L, Hb 140 g/L, platelet count 60 x 10(9)/L, and normal electrolytes and liver enzymes.
column24: A 25-year-old woman, G.S., presents to the genetics clinic with her mother due to concerns about her cognitive and physical development. She was born at 37 weeks gestation via cesarean section due to fetal distress, and had a low Apgar score. Her birth weight was 2.4 kg (5.3 lbs), and she had respiratory distress syndrome. G.S. has a flat nasal bridge, small jaw, and widely spaced eyes. She is unable to speak or walk independently and has difficulty sitting up without support. She has a history of seizures and frequent respiratory infections. Her developmental milestones are significantly delayed, and she has not achieved any significant cognitive or motor skills. G.S.'s mother reports that she has never been able to communicate effectively with her daughter and that she has always seemed "disconnected" from her surroundings. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have a small head size (microcephaly), short stature, and a prominent forehead. Her facial features include a flat nasal bridge, small jaw, widely spaced eyes, and a thin upper lip. She has postaxial polydactyly of her left hand and a single crease in her palmar surface.

column3:
Meet Emily, a 2-year-old girl who was born with Thanatophoric dysplasia. She has short arms and legs and a large head with a prominent forehead. Emily experiences frequent seizures and has difficulty breathing, which causes her to wheeze and turn blue. She is also developmentally delayed and cannot sit or stand without support. Despite these challenges, Emily is a happy and curious child who loves to play with toys and interact with her family.

Most important clinical features:

* Short limbs and small torso
* Large head with prominent forehead
* Respiratory problems (wheezing, difficulty breathing)
* Seizures
* Developmental delays (cannot sit or stand without support)
column10:
Meet Emily, a 25-year-old woman who has been experiencing shortness of breath and difficulty walking due to joint pain. She was born with Thanatophoric dysplasia, a condition that affects the development of her skeleton. Emily's height is only 4 feet 5 inches, and she has a characteristic dome-shaped skull. She also has short arms and legs, and her joints are swollen and painful. Despite her physical limitations, Emily remains positive and active, working as a graphic designer from home.
The most important clinical features of Thanatophoric dysplasia in this scenario include:
Short stature (4 feet 5 inches)
Dome-shaped skull
Short arms and legs
Joint deformities and pain
Respiratory problems (shortness of breath)
column17: A 2-day-old male newborn was transferred to our NICU from an outlying hospital due to respiratory distress and concern for skeletal dysplasia. The baby was born via emergency C-section at 37 weeks gestation because of fetal distress, with a birth weight of 2.4 kg (5.3 lbs). His Apgar score was 8 at 1 minute and 6 at 5 minutes. On examination, he was found to have a large head, prominent eyes, short limbs, and a bell-shaped thorax. He had redundant skin folds on his arms and legs, and his hands were in a trident configuration. He was hypotonic and had difficulty maintaining his airway, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. A chest X-ray showed a narrow thorax with flattened vertebral bodies, and bowed femurs were noted on ultrasound. The patient was diagnosed with Thanatophoric dysplasia type 1. Despite aggressive respiratory support, the baby's condition continued to deteriorate, and he died within 48 hours of life due to respiratory failure.
column24: Pt is a 25-year-old woman who presents to the office for a routine checkup. She was diagnosed with thanatophoric dysplasia (TD) at birth and has been followed by her primary care physician and geneticist since then. On examination, she is noted to have short stature, with a height of 4 feet 2 inches, and limb deformities, including bowed femurs and brachydactyly. Her head circumference is 56 cm, and she has frontal bossing, severe midface hypoplasia, and proptosis. Her thorax is narrow and bell-shaped, and there are redundant skin folds along her limbs. She also has generalized hypotonia. The patient reports that she has been experiencing some difficulty with balance and walking recently, and her neurological examination reveals some loss of coordination and muscle weakness. Imaging studies, including X-rays and CT scans, show significant craniosynostosis, temporal lobe dysplasia, hydrocephalus, and foramen magnum stenosis. The patient is referred to a neurosurgeon for further evaluation and management of her neurological symptoms. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of TD type 2.

column3:
A 3-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office for a routine well-child visit. His mother mentions that he has been growing rapidly and is now in the 90th percentile for height and weight. On examination, the child has a large head, a prominent forehead, and a short, broad nose. He also has a sacral dimple and a small patch of hair on his lower back. The child is developmentally delayed and has difficulty speaking in full sentences. His mother reports that he has been having trouble sleeping at night and often wakes up screaming.
The most important clinical features for this patient are:
* Large head
* Prominent forehead
* Short, broad nose
* Sacral dimple
* Patch of hair on lower back
* Developmental delay
* Difficulty speaking in full sentences
* Sleep disturbances
* Nighttime screaming
column10: A 25-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of persistent fatigue, weakness, and easy bruising. She also reports recurrent infections and delayed wound healing. On physical examination, she has a large tongue, a prominent forehead, and a short stature. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the CDKN1A gene. The patient is referred to a specialist for further management and monitoring.
column17: Patient: A 3-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office for a routine check-up. His mother mentions that he has been growing rapidly since birth and is now taller than his peers. The patient also has a large tongue that protrudes from his mouth, which causes difficulty with speech and sleep apnea. He was born with an omphalocele that was repaired surgically shortly after birth. The patient's blood work reveals mild hypoglycemia. Physical examination shows hemihyperplasia of the left side of his body, including his arm, leg, and facial features. There is also a noticeable anterior earlobe crease and posterior helical pit on his right ear. The patient's abdomen is enlarged, and imaging studies reveal visceromegaly of the liver and spleen. His family history is positive for a sibling with a similar condition. The patient is referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is suspected.
column24: A 30-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She has a history of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS), a growth disorder that she was diagnosed with as an infant. She reports that she had rapid growth in late fetal development and early childhood, but her growth rate slowed by age seven to eight years, resulting in an adult height within the normal range. She mentions that she has had issues with macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, neonatal hypoglycemia, and visceromegaly in the past, but these have not caused significant problems in recent years. However, she is concerned about the increased risk of embryonal tumor development associated with BWS, particularly given her family history of Wilms tumor. She also mentions that she has noticed some renal abnormalities and would like to discuss her options for managing these issues. The patient's physical examination reveals a number of characteristic clinical features of BWS, including macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, and anterior earlobe crease(s) and posterior helical pit(s). The physician orders imaging studies to further evaluate the patient's renal abnormalities and recommends regular monitoring and follow-up to manage her condition.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the dermatology clinic with a 2-year history of skin lesions that have been slowly increasing in number and size. The lesions are papillomatous, flesh-colored, and have a rough texture. They are primarily located on his chest, back, and face. He has also noticed recent worsening of the lesions, with some becoming inflamed and crusted. The patient has a family history of similar skin lesions in his mother and maternal grandfather.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a long history of skin lesions that have been slowly progressing over the past decade. She has numerous small, rough, brown papules on her chest, back, and arms. The papules are slightly itchy but not painful. She has tried various topical treatments without much improvement. Physical examination reveals characteristic stuck-on" appearance of the papules, with a distinct border and a smooth surface. There is no evidence of skin atrophy or scarring. The patient also reports having a strong family history of similar skin lesions in her mother and grandmother."
column17: Patient: 8-year-old girl, Sarah, presents to the dermatology clinic with her mother due to persistent skin lesions on her hands and feet that have been worsening over the past year. She also complains of dry, itchy skin and difficulty swallowing pills. Her mother reports that Sarah has had recurrent episodes of fever and vomiting, which seem to trigger the appearance of new lesions. On examination, the provider notes numerous keratotic papules on her trunk, acral pits on her palms and soles, and V-shaped notches on her fingernails. Sarah's mother also mentions that she has been experiencing difficulty with her schoolwork and has been more irritable than usual.
column24: Meet Sarah, a 35-year-old woman who has been struggling with a chronic skin condition since her early twenties. She has developed a variety of symptoms over the years, including keratotic papules on her trunk, acral pits on her palms and soles, and acral wart-like lesions on her hands that become worse after exposure to water. Her skin issues have significantly impacted her quality of life, causing her to feel self-conscious about her appearance and limiting her ability to participate in activities she enjoys. Sarah has also experienced nail abnormalities, such as V-shaped notches at the free edge of her nails, longitudinal red and white lines, ridging, and splitting. In addition to her skin issues, Sarah has been diagnosed with blepharitis, dry eye, and recurrent parotid gland obstruction. She has also experienced neuropsychiatric illness, including epilepsy and learning disabilities, which have further complicated her life. Despite trying various treatments, Sarah's symptoms continue to worsen, significantly impacting her overall health and well-being.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother due to concerns about his growth and development. He was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a birth weight of 2.8 kg. His mother reports that he has been growing slowly since birth and is currently below the 10th percentile for height and weight. On examination, the boy has a short stature, with a height of 80 cm, and a weight of 13 kg. He also has a prominent forehead, a flat nasal bridge, and a small jaw. His developmental milestones are delayed, and he is not yet speaking in full sentences. The boy's genetic testing reveals a mutation in the FGFR2 gene, consistent with Muenke syndrome.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of progressive hearing loss and respiratory problems. He has a distinctive facial appearance, including a flat nasal bridge, a small jaw, and widely spaced eyes. He also has short stature and a developmental delay. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the Muenke syndrome gene.
column17: A 3-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his concerned parents. They mention that he has been experiencing frequent ear infections and some difficulty with speech development. On examination, the boy is observed to have a turribrachycephaly skull shape, widely spaced eyes, mild ptosis, and high-arched palate. He also has bilateral coronal synostosis and brachydactyly of his thumbs. The patient's hearing test shows mild conductive hearing loss, and his developmental assessment suggests mild delays in speech and language skills. His parents also report some difficulties with behavior, including increased irritability and anxiety. Further neuroimaging studies reveal no evidence of elevated intracranial pressure or hydrocephalus. The patient is diagnosed with Muenke syndrome based on his clinical features and genetic testing results, which confirm the presence of a mutation in the FGFR2 ge
column24: A 35-year-old man with Muenke syndrome presents to the clinic for a follow-up appointment. He has a history of bilateral coronal synostosis, resulting in brachycephaly, and widely spaced eyes. He also has mild hearing loss and intellectual disability. The patient reports experiencing increased headaches and blurred vision recently. On examination, the patient has a prominent forehead, broad thumbs, and clinodactyly. His skull shows evidence of previous surgical intervention. A neuroimaging study reveals hydrocephalus, and an audiogram confirms the presence of sensorineural hearing loss. The patient is referred for further evaluation and management of his hydrocephalus and hearing loss. The most important clinical features in this case include brachycephaly, widely spaced eyes, intellectual disability, hearing loss, and hydrocephalus.

column3: A 4-year-old boy presents to the clinic with short stature and characteristic physical features, including a large head, prominent forehead, and short limbs. He has difficulty walking due to bowed legs and is unable to stand up straight. His parents have a consanguineous marriage and report similar symptoms in other family members. The patient's height is 80 cm (<3rd percentile), and his weight is 15 kg (25th-50th percentile).
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the office with a chief complaint of back pain and difficulty walking due to a short stature. He reports that he has always been short, but his height has not changed since he was a teenager. He also mentions that he has had recurring joint pain and stiffness, particularly in his knees and ankles, for the past few years. On physical examination, the patient's height is 4 feet 8 inches, and he has a characteristic swayback posture with a prominent abdomen and short limbs. His joints show signs of mild degenerative changes, and his gait is slow and unsteady. Imaging studies reveal a platyspondyly (flattened vertebrae) and shortened limbs. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Pseudoachondroplasia.
column17: Meet Emily, an almost 3-year-old girl who has been experiencing slow growth and difficulty walking since she began to crawl. Her parents have also noticed that her hands and feet appear short and wide, and her arms and legs seem to be somewhat deformed. Emily's joints are very flexible, especially in her hands, which causes her to have difficulty grasping objects. Despite her young age, Emily is experiencing early arthrosis and has developed a limp due to the deformation of her limbs. Her spine is also affected, causing lordosis, kyphosis, scoliosis, atlantoaxial dislocation, odontoid hypoplasia, platyspondyly, anterior flattening, and beaking of vertebrae. Emily's short stature and joint laxity make it difficult for her to perform everyday activities like walking or grasping objects. She has also developed a condition called brachydactyly, which causes her fingers to be short and stubby. Emily's parents are concerned about her development and have brought her to see a specialist.
column24: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic lower back pain and limited mobility in his elbows and hips. He has a history of joint pain and stiffness since childhood, which has progressively worsened over time. On examination, he has short stature (130 cm), brachydactyly, ulnar deviation of the wrists, limited elbow and hip extension, and ligamentous laxity. His spine shows lumbar lordosis, kyphosis, scoliosis, atlantoaxial dislocation, odontoid hypoplasia, platyspondyly, anterior flattening, and beaking of vertebrae. He also has fragmented and irregular epiphyses in his limbs. The patient is diagnosed with Pseudoachondroplasia, a rare genetic disorder that affects cartilage and bone development, leading to short-limb dwarfism, joint laxity, and early onset osteoarthropathy. The patient's condition is managed with pain medication, physical therapy, and lifestyle modifications such as regular exercise and weight management. Surgical interventions may be considered for severe cases of joint deformity or spinal instability.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his parents due to complaints of severe headache, nausea and vomiting. He has a history of recurrent headaches over the past year but they have been increasing in frequency and severity recently. The patient also reports of feeling tired and weak most of the time. On examination, he appears pale and wasted with a prominent forehead and a large tongue. His blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and his heart rate is 120 beats per minute. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of calcium, parathyroid hormone and pancreatic polypeptide.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
Severe headache
Nausea and vomiting
Pale and wasted appearance
Prominent forehead and large tongue
Elevated blood pressure and heart rate
Elevated levels of calcium, parathyroid hormone and pancreatic polypeptide.
column10:
A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal pain. She has a history of thyroid cancer that was diagnosed 5 years ago, and she had a total thyroidectomy at the time. She also has a family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). Physical examination reveals a firm mass in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen, and laboratory tests show elevated levels of calcium and parathyroid hormone.
The most important clinical features for this patient include:

* Personal history of thyroid cancer
* Family history of MEN1
* Abdominal pain
* Firm mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen
* Elevated levels of calcium and parathyroid hormone.
column17:
A 25-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 6-month history of fatigue, depression, and constipation. She also reports frequent urination and increased thirst. She has a family history of Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) and her older sister was diagnosed at the age of 28 with hyperparathyroidism. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg, heart rate of 96 beats per minute, and temperature of 37.2°C (99°F). Laboratory tests show serum calcium level of 12.5 mg/dL, parathyroid hormone (PTH) level of 180 pg/mL, and urine output of 2400 mL over 24 hours. The patient undergoes further imaging studies, which reveal a parathyroid adenoma. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of MEN1.
The most important clinical features in this case are:
* Family history of MEN1
* Hyperparathyroidism (elevated serum calcium and PTH levels)
* Symptoms of hypercalcemia
column24: Patient Vignette: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, depression, and constipation. She also mentions experiencing frequent urination and increased thirst. The patient's medical history reveals that she has a family history of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg, heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and temperature of 98.6°F (37°C). Laboratory tests show serum calcium levels of 12.5 mg/dL, parathyroid hormone level of 180 pg/mL, and urine calcium/creatinine ratio of 0.4. The patient undergoes further imaging studies, which reveal a parathyroid adenoma. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of MEN1.

column3: A 6-year-old boy named Max presents to the emergency department with his mother due to recurrent seizures that have been occurring for the past year. The seizures are often triggered by fever and occur once or twice a month, lasting around 30 minutes each. Max has also experienced developmental delays and has difficulty speaking in full sentences. He has a history of falling and injuring himself during seizures. His mother reports that he has been taking medication for epilepsy but has not shown significant improvement.
column10: A 35-year-old woman with Dravet syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that causes intractable epilepsy and developmental delays, presents to the emergency department (ED) with a 2-day history of worsening seizures. She has a history of poorly controlled seizures despite multiple medications and has been experiencing increasing frequency and severity of seizures over the past year. She has also noticed decreased coordination, balance difficulties, and slurred speech. On examination, she is lethargic and confused, with a decreased level of consciousness. Her vital signs are stable, but she has a fever of 101.3°F (38.5°C). The patient's electroencephalogram (EEG) shows a characteristic "spike-wave" pattern consistent with Dravet syndrome.
column17: A 4-year-old boy named Max presents to the emergency department after experiencing a prolonged seizure that started during his afternoon nap. His mother reports that he has been having recurrent seizures since he was 6 months old, often accompanied by fever and sometimes occurring in clusters. Max's developmental milestones were normal until age 2, but since then, his speech and motor skills have plateaued, and he has difficulty sleeping at night. He also seems to be sensitive to light and noise, which can trigger seizures. On examination, Max is lethargic and has a decreased responsiveness to his surroundings. His temperature is 102°F (39°C), and he has a slight left-sided weakness of his arm and leg. The rest of the neurological examination is normal. The emergency department physician suspects that Max might have Dravet syndrome and orders an electroencephalogram (EEG) and genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis
column24: A 35-year-old woman with Dravet syndrome presents to the clinic for follow-up. She was diagnosed at age 6 months, following her first seizure, and has been on various medications since then. Her seizures have been relatively well-controlled over the past few years, but she still experiences occasional breakthrough seizures, mostly during periods of stress or lack of sleep. She has a history of photosensitivity and has had to take precautions to avoid triggers such as bright lights or sun exposure. Despite her seizure disorder, she has been able to work part-time as a data entry clerk and lives independently with some support from family members. Her cognitive functioning is mildly impaired, but she is able to communicate effectively and perform daily tasks with some assistance. She has difficulty walking long distances due to her gait deterioration and uses a cane for support. The patient expresses frustration with the ongoing challenges of living with Dravet syndrome, but remains hopeful about new treatment options and advancements in research.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3:
A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of vomiting, diarrhea, and lethargy. The patient has a history of developmental delay and has been followed by a pediatrician for concerns of autism spectrum disorder. On examination, the patient is afebrile, but appears dehydrated and has a decreased level of consciousness. Laboratory studies reveal metabolic acidosis, hypoglycemia, and elevated liver enzymes. Urine organic acid analysis confirms the diagnosis of systemic primary carnitine deficiency.
The most important clinical features for this patient include:
1. Developmental delay
2. Vomiting and diarrhea
3. Lethargy
4. Dehydration
5. Metabolic acidosis
6. Hypoglycemia
7. Elevated liver enzymes
8. Positive urine organic acid analysis for carnitine deficiency.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, muscle weakness, and cramping. He also reports a history of recurrent episodes of confusion, disorientation, and seizures. The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder and has recently been experiencing increased tremors and difficulty walking. Physical examination reveals a thin, frail man with a BMI of 18.5 kg/m2. His blood work shows a low serum carnitine level, elevated CK, and metabolic acidosis. A diagnosis of systemic primary carnitine deficiency is suspected.
column17:
Patient: A 10-month-old male infant presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of vomiting, diarrhea, and lethargy. The patient's mother reports that he has been refusing to eat and has been increasingly irritable. On physical examination, the patient is afebrile but appears lethargic and dehydrated. His heart rate is 180 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg. The patient's liver is enlarged, and there is a mild splenomegaly. Laboratory results show a low serum carnitine level, elevated liver transaminases, and hyperammonemia.

The most important clinical features of this patient's presentation are:

* Hypoketotic hypoglycemia (low blood sugar without ketones)
* Poor feeding and irritability
* Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) and splenomegaly (enlarged spleen)
* Elevated liver transaminases and hyperammonemia
* History of recent upper respiratory tract infection
column24:
Patient: 35-year-old woman who presents to her primary care physician with a complaint of fatigue and decreased stamina over the past year. She also reports occasional palpitations and shortness of breath, especially during exercise. The patient has no significant medical history and has been otherwise healthy throughout her life.

Clinical features:

* Fatigue and decreased stamina
* Palpitations
* Shortness of breath during exercise
* No significant medical history
* Normal physical examination findings, except for a mild cardiac murmur
* Laboratory tests show low levels of carnitine in the blood
* Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the SLC22A5 gene, which codes for the carnitine transporter.

column3:
A 4-year-old boy named Jack presents to the pediatrician's office for a routine well-child visit. His mother reports that he has been having trouble gaining weight and has a weak cry. On examination, the child is noted to have a small stature, with a height of 30 inches (76 cm) and a weight of 28 pounds (12.7 kg). He also has a distinctive facial appearance, with a narrow forehead, long face, and thin upper lip. The child's appetite is increased, and he often wakes up at night to eat. His mother also reports that he has difficulty paying attention and following instructions.
The most important clinical features of this patient vignette are:
1. Small stature and low weight for age
2. Distinctive facial appearance
3. Increased appetite and nighttime eating
4. Difficulty with attention and following instructions
These features suggest a diagnosis of Prader-Willi syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects the hypothalamus and leads to abnormalities in appetite, growth, and cognitive function.
column10: A 35-year-old woman with Prader-Willi syndrome presents to the clinic for a routine checkup. She has a history of developmental delays, intellectual disability, and obesity. On examination, she has a short stature, small hands and feet, and a thin, fragile skin. She also has a characteristic facial appearance with a narrow forehead, long face, and a prominent chin. The patient has a history of hypothalamic dysfunction, which has led to hyperphagia (excessive eating) and obesity. She has also experienced recurrent seizures and sleep apnea. The patient is currently taking medication for seizure control and uses a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine at night to help manage her sleep apnea. Despite these challenges, the patient is friendly and outgoing, and she enjoys spending time with her family and friends.
column17: Meet Emily, a 4-year-old girl who was born with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS). Emily's parents noticed that she had difficulty feeding and gaining weight as an infant, and they were concerned about her slow development. When Emily turned one, they observed that she still couldn't sit up or crawl, and her speech was delayed. They also noticed that she had a weak muscle tone and poor coordination. As Emily grew older, her excessive eating habits became more apparent. She would constantly ask for food and drinks, even after finishing a meal. Her parents had to monitor her food intake closely to prevent obesity. Despite their efforts, Emily's weight continued to be a concern. She also showed signs of cognitive impairment, such as delayed language development and difficulty with social interactions. Emily's behavior was another area of concern for her parents. She would throw frequent tantrums when she didn't get what she wanted, and she had trouble following rules and instructions. Her parents worked closely with healthcare professionals to address these issues, but they found it challenging to manage her behavior. Emily's growth was monitored closely by her pediatrician, who suspected that she might have a growth hormone deficiency. She also had other associated endocrine abnormalities
column24: Ms. Smith is a 35-year-old woman who presents to the clinic with concerns about her weight and difficulty controlling her eating habits. She has a history of poor appetite and feeding difficulties in early infancy, followed by excessive eating and gradual development of morbid obesity in early childhood. Ms. Smith also reports delayed motor milestones and language development, as well as cognitive impairment and learning disabilities throughout her life. She has a distinctive facial appearance, including a narrow forehead, almond-shaped eyes, a thin upper lip, and down-turned mouth. Ms. Smith also reports hypogonadism, short stature, hypothyroidism, premature pubarche, and sleep-related breathing disorders. She has a history of temper tantrums, stubbornness, manipulative behavior, and obsessive-compulsive characteristics. The patient is currently 5 feet tall and weighs 250 pounds. Her BMI is 45.

column3: A 4-year-old boy named Max presents to the pediatrician's office for a routine well-child visit. His mother reports that he has been having some difficulty with speech and language development, and she notices that his face looks different from other children's faces. On examination, the pediatrician notes that Max has a distinctive facial appearance, with a flat nasal bridge, long eyelashes, and prominent ears. He also has mild intellectual disability and delayed speech and language skills. Genetic testing reveals that Max has Kabuki syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the KCNQ2 or KCNQ3 genes. The pediatrician refers Max to a multidisciplinary team of specialists for further evaluation and management of his condition.
column10: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her family because she has been experiencing fever, headache, and vomiting for the past 2 days. She has a history of Kabuki syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects multiple systems in the body. On examination, she has a distinctive facial appearance with a flat nasal bridge, long eyelashes, and prominent ears. She also has short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, consistent with an inflammatsory response. The patient is admitted for observation and management of her symptoms, and further evaluation is planned to determine the underlying cause of her presentation.
column17: Patient: A 4-year-old boy, Kai, presents to the clinic with his mother due to concerns about his growth and development. The mother reports that Kai has been having difficulty feeding and has had several respiratory infections in the past year. Kai was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a low birth weight. On physical exam, the provider notes that Kai has long palpebral fissures with eversion of the lateral third of his lower eyelid, arched and broad eyebrows, short columella with depressed nasal tip, large prominent ears, and mild hypotonia. The provider also observes a small head size, developmental delay, and intellectual disability. Further evaluation reveals a congenital heart defect, specifically an atrial septal defect, and kidney malformations. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Kabuki syndrome.
column24: A 35-year-old woman with Kabuki syndrome presents to the clinic for her annual checkup. She has a history of mild intellectual disability, seizures, and autoimmune disorders. On examination, she has typical facial features of Kabuki syndrome, including long palpebral fissures and arched eyebrows. She also has short stature and a small head size. Her heart sounds are normal, but she has a history of kidney malformations that have been monitored closely. She has missing teeth and wears glasses for near-sightedness. She reports experiencing recurrent infections throughout her life and has been diagnosed with growth hormone deficiency. Her developmental delay has affected her speech and language skills, but she is able to communicate effectively. She is currently working in a supported employment program and lives independently with some support. Despite the challenges associated with Kabuki syndrome, she leads an active and fulfilling life.

column3:
A 4-year-old boy named Max presents to the clinic with short stature and limb deformities. His height is below the 10th percentile, and he has a characteristic swayback posture. On examination, his arms and legs are short in comparison to his trunk, and he has a large head with a prominent forehead. His fingers are short and stubby, and he has a single crease across his palmar surface. Max's parents report that he has difficulty walking due to his short legs and has been delayed in reaching developmental milestones.
The most important clinical features of this patient vignette are:
Short stature
Limb deformities
Swayback posture
Large head with prominent forehead
Short fingers and single palmar crease
Delayed developmental milestones
These features suggest a diagnosis of Hypochondroplasia, a genetic disorder that affects the growth and development of cartilage and bone, leading to short stature and characteristic physical features.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the office with a chief complaint of back pain and difficulty standing up straight. He also mentions that he has noticed his arms and legs are somewhat shorter than those of his peers.
