On physical examination, the patient's height is measured at 4 feet 8 inches, and his limbs appear to be disproportionately short compared to his trunk. His spine appears to be curved, and he has a prominent forehead and a small jaw. The patient reports that he has had difficulty with employment due to his short stature and has felt self-conscious about his appearance for many years.
column17: Patient Vignette: Meet Emily, a 4-year-old girl who presents to the clinic with short stature and limb disproportion. Her height is below the 10th percentile for her age, and her arms and legs appear short in comparison to her trunk. She has a broad, short face and small hands and feet. Emily's parents also notice that she has difficulty keeping up with other children when playing, as she gets tired easily. On examination, the clinician notes mild joint laxity and macrocephaly. Radiologic evaluation reveals shortening of long bones with mild metaphyseal flare, narrowing of the inferior lumbar interpedicular distances, short broad femoral neck, and squared, shortened ilia. Emily's intellectual development is normal, but she has experienced occasional seizures. The clinician suspects that Emily may have hypochondroplasia and refers her for further genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis.
column24: A 35-year-old woman with hypochondroplasia presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up appointment. She is 140 cm tall and has a stocky build, with short arms and legs and broad hands and feet. She has mild joint laxity and macrocephaly. The patient reports occasional back pain and difficulty walking long distances due to fatigue. On examination, her blood pressure is normal, and there are no signs of respiratory or cardiovascular disease. Radiographs show shortening of the long bones with mild metaphyseal flare, narrowing of the inferior lumbar interpedicular distances, a short broad femoral neck, and squared, shortened ilia. The patient's intellectual function is normal, but she has a history of seizures that are well-controlled with medication. The most important clinical features in this case are the short stature, limb disproportion, joint laxity, macrocephaly, and history of seizures, which are all consistent with the diagnosis of hypochondroplasia.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a history of bleeding gums and easy bruising over the past year. He also reports frequent joint pain and swelling, especially in his knees and elbows. The patient has a family history of hemophilia B, and his father was diagnosed with the same condition when he was a child. Physical examination reveals petechiae on his arms and legs, as well as signs of joint effusion in his left knee. Laboratory tests confirm the presence of factor IX deficiency, consistent with hemophilia B.
column10:
A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe left knee pain and swelling after falling onto a hard surface. He has a history of hemophilia B and is taking factor IX concentrate as prophylaxis. On examination, his vital signs are normal, but he has marked tenderness and swelling over the left knee joint. There is no evidence of an open wound or bleeding. The patient's blood work shows a low level of factor IX activity.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
1. Sudden onset of severe knee pain and swelling
2. History of hemophilia B
3. Low level of factor IX activity
4. No evidence of open wound or bleeding
5. Use of factor IX concentrate as prophylaxis.
column17: Patient: John, a 4-year-old boy who has been experiencing joint pain and swelling in his knees and elbows for the past year. He also has had recurrent nosebleeds and bruising after minor falls. His mother reports that he often complains of headaches and has difficulty walking due to joint stiffness. John's medical history reveals a family history of hemophilia B, as his older brother was diagnosed with the disorder at a young age. Physical examination shows swollen and painful joints, particularly in the knees and elbows, and multiple bruises on his arms and legs. Laboratory tests confirm a low level of factor IX clotting activity, consistent with a diagnosis of hemophilia B. The most important clinical features in this case are: family history of hemophilia B, joint pain and swelling, recurrent nosebleeds, bruising, and low levels of factor IX clotting activity.
column24: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute left knee pain after falling from a bike. He has a history of hemophilia B and is on prophylactic factor IX infusions every 2 weeks. On examination, his knee is swollen and tender with an effusion. The patient reports that he has been experiencing increasing pain over the past few hours. His most recent factor IX infusion was 1 week ago. The patient's vital signs are normal. The patient is diagnosed with a left knee hemarthrosis and is treated with factor IX concentrate, analgesics, and rest. The patient is advised to avoid any strenuous activities that may exacerbate the condition and is referred for physical therapy to help recover range of motion and strength in his knee. The most important clinical features in this scenario are: acute knee pain, swelling, and tenderness; history of hemophilia B; recent fall; and the presence of an effusion. These findings suggest a bleeding episode in the knee joint, which is a common complication in patients with hemophilia B. The patient's history of hemophilia B and recent factor IX infusion also help to support this diagnosis.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother due to concerns about his growth and development. He was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a low birth weight. His mother reports that he has always been small for his age and has struggled to gain weight. On examination, the patient is noted to have a short stature, with a height of 105 cm (25th percentile). He also has a prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, and a small jaw. His fingers are short and tapered, and he has a single crease in his palm. The patient's developmental milestones have been delayed, and he has difficulty with speech and language skills. A diagnosis of Saethre-Chotzen syndrome is suspected based on the patient's clinical features.
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe headache, fever, and confusion. He has a history of Saethre-Chotzen syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by craniofacial abnormalities and intellectual disability. On examination, he has a prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, and a short nose. His vital signs are normal except for a temperature of 102°F (39°C). He is lethargic and unable to answer questions coherently. A non-contrast CT scan reveals a large frontal lobe abscess.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:

* Prominent forehead
* Widely spaced eyes
* Short nose
* Lethargy
* Fever
* Confusion
* History of Saethre-Chotzen syndrome
* Large frontal lobe abscess on CT scan.
column17: A 3-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of delayed speech development and difficulty sleeping. On examination, he has a characteristic appearance of the ear (small pinna with a prominent superior and/or inferior crus), strabismus, ptosis, and facial asymmetry. His hand shows broad toes, partial cutaneous syndactyly of digits 2 and 3, and duplicated distal phalanx of the hallux. The patient's head shape is abnormal with a low frontal hairline and his skull sutures are fused. He has mild intellectual disability and sleep apnea. The patient is diagnosed with Saethre-Chotzen syndrome, a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the TWIST1 or EFTUD2 gene.
column24: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with a lifetime history of facial asymmetry, small ears, and ptosis. He also reports having had strabismus surgery as a child. On examination, he has a prominent superior and inferior crus of his ears, broad toes, and partial cutaneous syndactyly of digits 2 and 3 of the hand. His skull shape is abnormal with a low frontal hairline and a prominent forehead. He also has mild hypertelorism and maxillary hypoplasia. The patient's intelligence is normal, but he reports having had some developmental delays in childhood. He has no known history of sleep apnea or other medical conditions. Family history is unremarkable. Genetic testing reveals a deletion of the TWIST1 gene, consistent with Saethre-Chotzen syndrome. The patient is referred for further evaluation and management by a multidisciplinary team, including neurosurgery, ophthalmology, orthopedics, and genetics.

column1: Glycogen storage disease due to acid maltase deficiency
column3:
A 3-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent episodes of vomiting, lethargy, and hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) after consuming foods containing carbohydrates. He also experiences frequent respiratory infections and has difficulty gaining weight. On examination, he appears pale and wasted, with a prominent forehead and enlarged liver. His blood work reveals low levels of glucose and high levels of lactic acid. The patient is diagnosed with glycogen storage disease due to acid maltase deficiency.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
- Recurrent episodes of vomiting, lethargy, and hypoglycemia after consuming carbohydrates
- Frequent respiratory infections
- Difficulty gaining weight
- Pale and wasted appearance
- Prominent forehead
- Enlarged liver
- Low levels of glucose and high levels of lactic acid on blood work.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute respiratory distress and confusion. He has a history of glycogen storage disease (GSD) due to acid maltase deficiency, which he has been managing with a strict diet and enzyme replacement therapy. However, he recently started experiencing worsening muscle weakness and fatigue, leading to difficulty breathing and swallowing. On examination, the patient is lethargic and confused, with a decreased level of consciousness. He has signs of respiratory distress, including tachypnea and use of accessory muscles. His muscle strength is severely diminished, and he has difficulty speaking and swallowing. The most important clinical features in this scenario are the patient's history of GSD, his recent worsening symptoms, and the presence of respiratory distress and altered mental status. These findings suggest that the patient is experiencing a severe metabolic crisis, which requires immediate medical attention and intervention.
column17: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening respiratory distress, poor feeding, and decreased activity level. The patient was previously healthy but has recently been experiencing increasing difficulty breathing, especially when lying down. On examination, the patient is tachypneic, with a rate of 40 breaths per minute, and has moderate respiratory distress. His blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, heart rate 120 beats per minute, and body temperature 37°C (98.6°F). The patient's liver and spleen are enlarged, and there is a significant diaphragmatic paralysis. He has firm muscles, proximal muscle weakness, and a myopathic pattern on EMG. The patient also experiences macroglossia, cardiomegaly, shortened P-R interval on EKG, huge QRS complexes, and Wolf-Parkinson-White syndrome. A diagnosis of glycogen storage disease due to acid maltase deficiency is suspected, and further laboratory tests are ordered to confirm the diagnosis. The patient is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit for close monitoring and management of respiratory failure.
column24: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain. He has a history of progressive muscle weakness over the past year, which has made it difficult for him to walk or perform daily activities. He also reports frequent respiratory infections and has had recurrent pneumonia. On examination, he has a large tongue and an enlarged liver. His heart sounds are abnormal with a shortened P-R interval and huge QRS complexes on his EKG. He is diagnosed with glycogen storage disease due to acid maltase deficiency, a rare lysosomal storage disorder that affects the muscles, liver, and respiratory system. The patient's muscle weakness and respiratory failure are caused by the accumulation of glycogen in his muscles and organs, leading to impaired muscle function and respiratory insufficiency. He is admitted to the hospital for further management and treatment.

column3:
A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. He has a history of recurrent stroke-like episodes, seizures, and developmental delays. On examination, he has left hemiparesis, dysarthria, and ataxia. MRI shows cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy-subcortical infarcts-leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL). Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis.
The most important clinical features of this patient's presentation are:
Sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking
History of recurrent stroke-like episodes, seizures, and developmental delays
Left hemiparesis, dysarthria, and ataxia on examination
MRI showing cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy-subcortical infarcts-leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL)
column10:
A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. She has a history of hypertension and smoking, but no previous neurological events. On examination, she has left hemiparesis, dysarthria, and gaze palsy. CT scan shows a small subcortical infarction in the right frontal lobe. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the NOTCH3 gene, consistent with cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy-subcortical infarcts-leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL).
The most important clinical features of this patient's presentation are:
Sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking
History of hypertension and smoking
Left hemiparesis, dysarthria, and gaze palsy on examination
Small subcortical infarction in the right frontal lobe on CT scan
Positive genetic testing for NOTCH3 mutation, consistent with CADASIL.
column17: A 10 year old boy presents to the emergency room after experiencing sudden weakness and numbness on his right side, difficulty speaking and understanding speech, and vision loss in his left eye. He had been complaining of headaches for a week prior to admission. His past medical history is significant for migraines with aura since he was 5 years old. Family history reveals that his mother had a similar condition when she was in her mid-40s, and his maternal grandfather died suddenly at the age of 60. On examination, the boy has left hemiparesis, left homonymous hemianopsia, dysarthria, and aphasia. His National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score is 18. Urgent non-contrast head CT scan shows an area of hypodensity in the right frontal lobe consistent with an acute infarction. The patient is given tissue plasminogen activator and transferred to a comprehensive stroke center for further management.
column24: Meet Sarah, a 48-year-old woman who has been experiencing recurrent ischemic strokes and cognitive decline over the past few years. She has a history of migraines with aura, dating back to her early 30s, and has been experiencing increasing mood disturbances, apathy, and personality changes. Sarah's most recent stroke occurred six months ago, which led to a significant decline in her cognitive abilities, including difficulty with speech, memory loss, and difficulty with daily activities. She has also been experiencing worsening depression and anxiety, which has made it difficult for her to perform daily tasks and maintain her job. Sarah's neuroimaging results show diffuse white matter lesions and subcortical infarcts, which are consistent with Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy-subcortical infarcts-leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL). Her medical history, clinical presentation, and neuroimaging findings are consistent with this diagnosis.

column3:
A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his parents due to complaints of headache, nausea and vomiting. He has a history of recurrent headaches over the past year but they have been increasing in frequency and severity recently. The patient also reports of feeling tired and weak most of the time. On examination, he appears pale and wasted with a prominent forehead and a large tongue. His blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and his heart rate is 120 beats per minute. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
- Recurrent headaches
- Fatigue
- Weakness
- Pale and wasted appearance
- Prominent forehead and large tongue
- Elevated blood pressure and heart rate
- Elevated levels of calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen
column10:
A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of a mass in his neck that has been growing over the past year. He also reports fatigue, weight loss, and muscle weakness. Physical examination reveals a large goiter with a firm, nodular texture. The patient is referred to an endocrinologist for further evaluation. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA). Imaging studies demonstrate a thyroid mass that is consistent with a medullary thyroid carcinoma. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2).
The most important clinical features for this patient include:

* A growing neck mass
* Symptoms of fatigue, weight loss, and muscle weakness
* Elevated levels of calcitonin and CEA on laboratory tests
* Imaging studies consistent with a medullary thyroid carcinoma
* Confirmation of MEN2 diagnosis through genetic testing.
column17: A 7-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother, who is concerned about his swollen neck. The boy has had a slowly growing mass in his neck for several months, which has recently become more prominent. He also complains of difficulty swallowing and frequent coughing. Physical examination reveals a firm, non-tender thyroid mass, and the patient has a distinctive appearance with large lips, a long face, and a high-arched palate. The patient's mother mentions that he has had recurrent respiratory infections and difficulty breathing at night. Further evaluation reveals elevated calcitonin levels and a positive genetic test for Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). Imaging studies show a large, invasive medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) with regional lymph node metastasis. The patient is referred to surgery for thyroidectomy and will require ongoing monitoring for potential development of pheochromocytoma or primary hyperparathyroidism.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 6-month history of fatigue, weight loss, and anxiety. She also reports a recent onset of tremors and palpitations. On physical examination, she has an increased heart rate and blood pressure, moist skin, and a prominent thyroid nodule. Laboratory tests reveal hyperthyrotropinemia and elevated calcitonin levels. The patient undergoes ultrasonography, which shows a large, solid thyroid mass consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A), and she is referred to an endocrinologist for further management.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of vomiting, lethargy, and decreased oral intake. The patient has a history of developmental delay and has been losing weight over the past year. On examination, he is afebrile, tachypneic, and has a weak muscle tone. His respiratory rate is 32 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient is unable to stand or walk without support. He has a positive doll's eye reflex and a negative meningism sign. Laboratory results show a serum lactate of 12 mmol/L, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 30 mg/dL, creatinine of 1.5 mg/dL, and an arterial pH of 7.42. Urinalysis shows a specific gravity of 1.010, proteinuria of 1+, and ketonuria of 2+. The patient's blood culture is positive for Haemophilus influenzae type b.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. He has a history of gradually worsening muscle weakness over several years, which he attributed to "being out of shape." He denies any recent travel or illness. On examination, he has left-sided hemiparesis, dysarthria, and difficulty walking. His reflexes are hyperactive, and his plantar response is extensor. He has a history of similar episodes in the past that have resolved on their own.
column17: A 10-month-old boy, John, was brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to concerns about his development. They reported that he had been vomiting frequently and had lost interest in playing with toys. John had also become increasingly lethargic and had difficulty controlling his head movements. On examination, John's muscle tone was found to be decreased, and he had difficulty sitting up without support. His eyes showed a characteristic "dancing" movement (nystagmus), and he had difficulty tracking objects visually. The physician also noted some unusual postures and movements of his limbs. John was diagnosed with Leigh syndrome based on these symptoms, and genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis.
column24: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of worsening left arm weakness, difficulty speaking, and double vision. She had been previously healthy except for mild, intermittent nausea and vomiting over the past year. On examination, she has left-sided hemiparesis, ataxic speech, and horizontal nystagmus. Fundoscopy shows bilateral papilledema. Her blood work reveals a lactic acidosis, and her MRI scan shows an abnormal signal in the basal ganglia and brainstem. Genetic testing is pending but clinical suspicion for Leigh syndrome is high.

column3:
A 2-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a history of recurrent seizures and developmental delay. He has a strong odor of sweaty feet, and his skin is dry and rough. His mother reports that he has been having trouble walking and standing, and he often falls. The patient's urine output and protein intake are normal. A plasma amino acid analysis reveals elevated levels of 3-methylcrotonic acid and 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency.
The most important clinical features for this patient include:
* Developmental delay
* Recurrent seizures
* Strong odor of sweaty feet
* Dry, rough skin
* Trouble walking and standing
* Elevated levels of 3-methylcrotonic acid and 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid in plasma amino acid analysis
* Confirmation of diagnosis through genetic testing.
column10: A 27-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of recurrent episodes of vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea over the past year. She has also noticed that her hair has become brittle and easily breaks. On physical examination, she has a thin, wasted appearance and signs of dehydration. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated level of 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase enzyme in her blood, consistent with a diagnosis of 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency.
column17: A 24-month-old boy was brought to the emergency room after experiencing vomiting, lethargy, and seizures following a viral gastroenteritis. He had previously been healthy and developmentally normal. On examination, he had a temperature of 38.5°C, blood pressure of 70/40 mmHg, tachycardia, and tachypnea. His blood gas analysis revealed a pH of 7.2, pCO2 50 mmHg, pO2 60 mmHg, HCO3 10 mmol/L, base excess -4 mmol/L, and lactate 5 mmol/L. His urine output, protein intake, and lipid profile were normal. Genetic testing revealed a compound heterozygote mutation in the 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase gene (MCCC1). The patient was diagnosed with 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency (3-MCCD), and he received appropriate treatment, including intravenous fluids, anticonvulsants, and a low-protein diet.
column24: Meet Sarah, a 27-year-old woman who presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of vomiting, confusion, and seizures. She had been feeling unwell for a few days, but her symptoms rapidly worsened over the past 24 hours. Sarah has a history of intermittent fasting and had recently started a high-protein diet. On examination, she was lethargic, with a weak muscle tone and difficulty speaking. Her blood work revealed an increased level of 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency biomarkers, consistent with an organic aciduria. Further investigation revealed that Sarah had a history of recurrent metabolic crises, which were triggered by fasting and protein-rich diets. She was diagnosed with 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to break down certain amino acids. Sarah was treated with intravenous fluids, electrolyte supplementation, and a low-protein diet. She recovered fully and was advised to avoid fasting and follow a balanced diet to prevent future metabolic crises.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother, who is concerned about her son's vision and skin condition. The boy has pale skin, light blond hair, and blue eyes. He has difficulty seeing objects at a distance and struggles with reading the blackboard in class. His skin is hypopigmented, and he has several freckles on his face and arms. The mother reports that her son has had multiple sunburns despite using sunscreen and protective clothing. The patient's medical history includes nystagmus and strabismus surgery when he was 3 years old. Family history is unremarkable.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a long history of skin problems. He has very fair skin, light hair, and blue eyes. He reports that he has had multiple skin cancers removed over the years, including several basal cell carcinomas and squamous cell carcinomas. He also experiences frequent sunburns, even when using sunscreen. He is concerned about his risk of developing melanoma. On examination, his skin is pale and freckled, with numerous nevi and actinic keratoses.
column17:
Patient: A 3-year-old boy, John, presents to the pediatrician's office for a routine check-up. His parents mention that he has been having difficulty seeing objects at a distance and that his eyes seem to move rapidly when looking at things. John was born with light brown hair and skin and has had nystagmus since he was 2 months old. He also has strabismus and often appears to be looking off into the distance. The patient's visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes, and his irises are gray. John's skin is rough and coarse, with several solar keratoses on his face and arms. His hair has darkened over time but still appears lighter than that of his siblings. The patient has no history of melanoma or other cancers in his family. \n\nThe most important clinical features of this patient's presentation are:
1. Nystagmus
2. Strabismus
3. Poor visual acuity (20/100)
4. Gray irises
5. Rough, coarse skin with solar keratoses
6. Light brown hair that has darkened over time
7. No family history of melanoma or other cancers.
column24: Ms. Smith is a 35-year-old woman who presents to the eye clinic with a long history of nystagmus and poor vision. She has had difficulty seeing objects clearly since early childhood and has been using telescopes and other visual aids to assist her vision. She has light brown hair, creamy white skin, and gray irises. Upon examination, she is found to have strabismus and visual inattention. Her visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes, and she has a mild degree of solar keratoses on her face and arms. She is diagnosed with oculocutaneous albinism type 2 (OCA2), which is confirmed by genetic testing. Despite her visual limitations, Ms. Smith is an independent and active individual who enjoys outdoor activities such as hiking and biking. She is counseled on the importance of sun protection and advised to have regular skin examinations to monitor for any potential skin cancers.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother, who is concerned about the appearance of his skin. The boy has had a history of easily bruising and developing small, firm papules on his skin since he was a toddler. Recently, the papules have been increasing in number and size, and some have started to turn yellowish-brown. The mother also notices that her son's skin seems to be losing its elasticity and appears "baggy" in certain areas. The boy is otherwise healthy and has no other medical conditions.
column10: A 45-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a long history of gradually worsening skin lesions. She has yellowish, small papules on her face, neck, and arms that have become more numerous over time. The papules are slightly scaly and do not itch or bleed. She also has a history of spontaneous bruising, particularly on her arms and legs. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. Family history reveals a similar skin condition in her mother and maternal grandmother. Examination shows numerous small, yellowish papules on the face, neck, and arms, with some having a characteristic "cobblestone" appearance. There are also several large, bruise-like patches on her arms and legs. The patient has a mild anemia but normal coagulation studies. Biopsy of one of the papules shows fragmentation of elastic fibers in the dermis.
column17: A 10-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother, who is concerned about small yellow papules on the nape and sides of his neck and in flexural areas. The child has also been experiencing intermittent claudication of arm and leg muscles. On examination, the patient appears healthy, but there are multiple small, soft, yellowish papules on the neck, axillae, and groin. There is no evidence of cardiovascular or gastrointestinal disease. Ophthalmologic evaluation reveals angioid streaks in both eyes. Further diagnostic testing shows normal renal function, and echocardiography does not demonstrate any significant cardiac abnormalities. The patient is diagnosed with Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE), and the mother is informed that this is a systemic disorder that affects the elastic tissue of the skin, eye, and vascular system. The patient will require regular monitoring for potential complications such as reduced vision, premature gastrointestinal angina and/or bleeding, intermittent claudication of arm and leg muscles, stroke, renovascular hypertension, and cardiovascular complications (angina/myocardial infarction).
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 10-year history of progressive vision loss, particularly in the central visual field. She also reports experiencing intermittent claudication in her legs and arms, as well as recurrent gastrointestinal bleeding. On physical examination, the patient has yellow papules on her neck and flexural areas, and her skin appears loose and wrinkled. Funduscopic examination reveals angioid streaks in both eyes. The patient is referred to a specialist for further evaluation and management of her condition.

column3:
Meet 3-year-old Sarah, who was born with Leber congenital amaurosis. She has never been able to see objects or people clearly, and her eyes often move involuntarily. Despite this, she has developed coping mechanisms such as using her other senses to navigate her environment. Sarah's parents have noticed that she is delayed in reaching certain developmental milestones, such as walking and speaking. They have also observed that she is sensitive to bright lights and often covers her eyes when exposed to them.

Most important clinical features:

* Congenital blindness or severe visual impairment
* Nystagmus (involuntary eye movements)
* Strabismus (crossed eyes)
* Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
* Delayed development of motor skills and cognitive abilities.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a long history of progressive vision loss, starting from childhood. He has never been able to see well and has always had difficulty recognizing objects or people beyond a few feet away. On examination, visual acuity is count fingers at 1 foot, and there is no light perception. Funduscopic examination shows a normal-sized optic disc, but the retina appears abnormal with pigmentary changes and attenuation of retinal vessels. Fluorescein angiography reveals a characteristic "sea fan" pattern in the early phases, indicating widespread retinal pigment epithelial degeneration. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Leber congenital amaurosis.
column17:
Patient: John Age: 3 years Gender: Male

Chief Complaint:"My son has been having trouble seeing and moving his eyes since he was born. He also keeps poking, rubbing, and pressing his eyes a lot."

History of Present Illness: John was born at 37 weeks gestation via cesarean section for fetal distress. His Apgar score was 8/9. He had a prolonged neonatal stay for hyperbilirubinemia, which resolved with phototherapy. At 6 months of age, his mother noticed that he wasn't tracking objects and his eyes seemed to be moving all around. She also observed that he would poke, rub, and press his eyes frequently. John had a normal physical exam at birth, but developmental delays were noticed early on. He sat up at 12 months, crawled at 14 months, and started walking independently at 18 months. His speech is limited to a few words such as momma and dada. He doesn't seem interested in playing with toys or interacting with other kids. John has been using glasses for +5 diopters since he was 2 years old, but it hasn't seemed to help much. His pupils appear small and don't react to light.
column24:
Patient: John, a 35-year-old male
Chief Complaint: Lifelong severe visual impairment and difficulty with mobility
History of Present Illness: John was born with severe visual impairment and has had difficulty seeing objects and people since early childhood. He has never been able to read print or recognize faces, and has relied on auditory cues to navigate his environment. Despite his visual limitations, John has learned to adapt and uses assistive technology to assist him in daily tasks. He has also developed nystagmus and oculodigital sign (poking, rubbing, and/or pressing of the eyes) over time. Recently, John has experienced some difficulty with balance and mobility.
Past Medical History: John was diagnosed with Leber congenital amaurosis at a young age, and has been followed by an ophthalmologist regularly. He has also been diagnosed with intellectual disability and neurodevelopmental delay.
Family History: John's parents are consanguineous, and he has several siblings who are also affected with similar visual impairments.
Social History: John lives independently and works at a sheltered workshop. He uses assistive technology to communicate and navigate his environment. Despite his visual limitations, John is active in his community and enjoys participating in sports and other recreational activities.

column3: A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of vomiting, diarrhea, and fever. She has been experiencing muscle weakness and cramping, especially in her legs. On examination, she is dehydrated, tachycardic, and has a decreased level of consciousness. Laboratory tests reveal hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, and elevated creatine kinase levels. The patient is diagnosed with Gitelman syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to regulate electrolyte levels.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 2-month history of muscle weakness, fatigue, and cramping. She also reports frequent urination and thirst. On examination, she has mild hypotension, tachycardia, and mild muscle wasting. Laboratory tests reveal hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and a high urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio. The patient is diagnosed with Gitelman syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the SLC12A3 gene that codes for the thiazide-sensitive sodium chloride cotransporter.
column17: A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a complaint of recurrent episodes of muscle weakness and tetany over the past year, accompanied by abdominal pain. She also reports excessive thirst and nocturia. On examination, she has hypotonia, and her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Laboratory tests show hypokalemia (2.5 mEq/L), metabolic alkalosis (pH 7.48, HCO3 24 mmol/L, CO2 14 mmol/L), and a mild increase in plasma aldosterone concentration (PAC) of 15 ng/dL. The patient is diagnosed with Gitelman syndrome based on clinical features and laboratory results. Genetic testing identifies a homozygous mutation in the SLC12A3 gene, confirming the diagnosis. Treatment includes potassium supplements, sodium restriction, and regular monitoring of electrolytes and blood pressure.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 2-month history of fatigue, muscle weakness, and tetany. She also reports a long history of salt craving and nocturia. Physical examination reveals a slightly short stature (150 cm), but no other dysmorphic features. Blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Laboratory tests show hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and elevated urinary potassium excretion. The patient is referred to a nephrologist for further evaluation. She is diagnosed with Gitelman syndrome based on clinical features and laboratory results. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother, who is concerned about her son's vision and skin condition. The boy has pale skin, light blond hair, and blue eyes. He has difficulty seeing objects at a distance and experiences frequent sunburns despite using sunscreen. His mother also notices that he has difficulty navigating in bright lighting conditions. The patient has a family history of albinism and his father has the same condition.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a long history of skin problems. He has very fair skin, light hair, and blue eyes. He reports that he has had multiple skin cancers removed over the years, including several melanomas. He also experiences visual disturbances, such as nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) and photophobia (sensitivity to light). He has difficulty seeing in bright lighting conditions and has trouble with depth perception. The patient is concerned about his skin and eyes, and he wants to know if there is a way to prevent further damage.
column17: A 6 year old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother, who is concerned about her son's vision and skin. The boy has very light skin, hair and eyes, almost white in color. He squints a lot when outside and holds books close to his face when reading. His visual acuity is 20/400 and he has nystagmus. The mother mentions that the boy gets sunburned easily and has difficulty tolerating bright lights. The patient has a family history of similar symptoms in his siblings and parents.
column24: A 28 year old woman presents to the eye clinic with a lifelong history of vision problems. She has very light skin, hair and eyes and reports difficulty seeing in bright lighting conditions. On examination, she has nystagmus and reduced visual acuity.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmologist's office with complaints of blurry vision and difficulty seeing in dim lighting. He has a history of wearing glasses since the age of 5, but his vision has been steadily declining over the past year. His parents also notice that he has difficulty navigating stairs and often bumps into objects. On examination, visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes, with a prominent scotoma in the central vision of both eyes. Funduscopic examination reveals a characteristic "bone-spicule" pattern in the retina, with areas of atrophy and pigmentary changes. The patient is diagnosed with cone-rod dystrophy, a rare genetic disorder that affects the retina and causes progressive vision loss.
column10:
A 45-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a long history of progressive vision loss, beginning in his early 30s. He has difficulty recognizing faces and reading standard print, even with corrective glasses. He notices that colors appear faded and has trouble seeing in low light environments. He has a family history of similar symptoms in his mother and maternal grandfather.
On examination, visual acuity is 20/70 in the right eye and 20/100 in the left eye. Funduscopic examination reveals a characteristic bone-spicule pattern of retinal degeneration, with areas of hypopigmentation and atrophy. Electroretinography (ERG) confirms the diagnosis of cone-rod dystrophy.
The patient is referred for genetic counseling to discuss possible inheritance patterns and implications for his children. He is also advised to avoid activities that may exacerbate the condition, such as driving at night or operating heavy machinery. Low vision aids and assistive technology are recommended to improve his quality of life.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
1. Progressive vision loss starting in early adulthood
2. Difficulty with color perception and low light vision
column17: A 10-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of difficulty seeing in dim lighting and difficulty reading small print. He also reports that colors appear faded and he has trouble distinguishing between certain shades of blue and green. On examination, visual acuity is 20/50 in both eyes, and funduscopic examination reveals widespread retinal pigmentation and atrophy of the central and peripheral retina. Electroretinography (ERG) shows a marked reduction in cone and rod responses. The patient is diagnosed with cone-rod dystrophy, and genetic testing confirms the presence of a mutation in one of the genes associated with the condition.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a long history of progressive vision loss, beginning in her early twenties. She initially noticed difficulty distinguishing colors and has since developed nyctalopia (night blindness) and peripheral visual field loss. On examination, visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes, with mild pigmentation of the retina and chorioretinal atrophy in the central and peripheral fundus. Electroretinography (ERG) shows a marked reduction in cone responses, consistent with Cone-rod dystrophy (CORD). The patient is referred for genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis and counseling regarding potential therapeutic options.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with lethargy, poor appetite, and vomiting for the past 2 days. He was recently started on a ketogenic diet for intractable epilepsy. On examination, he has a weak cry, sunken eyes, and a dry mouth. His blood work reveals a serum ammonia level of 150 mg/dL and a citrulline level of <5 mg/dL. Urine organic acids show elevated levels of citrulline and ammonia. The child is diagnosed with Citrullinemia type I, a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme argininosuccinate synthetase.
column10:
A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. He has a history of poor appetite and fatigue for the past week. He appears lethargic and confused, with a temperature of 102°F (39°C). His blood work reveals a serum ammonia level of 150 mg/dL (normal range: 15-40 mg/dL), citrulline level of 0.2 mg/dL (normal range: 10-30 mg/dL), and arginase activity of 0.2 U/mL (normal range: 0.5-2.0 U/mL). Urine organic acid analysis shows a marked increase in citrulline excretion.
The most important clinical features for this patient include:
Severe headache, nausea, and vomiting
Lethargy and confusion
Elevated serum ammonia level
Low citrulline level
Decreased arginase activity
Increased citrulline excretion in urine organic acid analysis.
column17: A 3-month old male infant presents to the emergency department with lethargy, poor feeding, and vomiting. The parents report that he has been sleeping more than usual and is not as active as he was a few days ago. On examination, the patient is pale, has a weak cry, and is breathing rapidly. He has a large head circumference and a prominent forehead. There is no evidence of liver dysfunction or coagulopathy. Laboratory tests show an elevated ammonia level and low levels of argininosuccinate synthase enzyme activity. The patient is diagnosed with Citrullinemia type I, and treatment is initiated promptly to prevent further neurological damage.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of headache, nausea, and vomiting. She is confused and lethargic. Her husband reports that she has not been eating well for several days. On examination, her vital signs are normal except for a temperature of 38.1°C (100.6°F). She has asterixis and positive oculogyric reflex. The rest of the neurological examination is non-focal. Laboratory results show a serum ammonia level of 247 μmol/L (normal range, 15–60 μmol/L), aspartate transaminase 80 IU/L (normal range, 10–35 IU/L), and alanine transaminase 120 IU/L (normal range, 7–50 IU/L). Abdominal ultrasound shows a normal liver. The patient is treated with intravenous sodium benzoate and arginine hydrochloride, and her ammonia levels trend downward over the next 24 hours. She becomes more alert and awake, and her asterixis resolves. Genetic testing reveals two pathogenic variants in the CTLN1 gene

column3:
A 10-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office with her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's recent symptoms. The girl has been experiencing abdominal pain and diarrhea for several weeks, and has also noticed some small, dark spots on her skin. She has a history of recurrent respiratory infections and has had to miss school several times due to illness. Her mother mentions that the girl's father died of cancer when she was a baby, and that there is a family history of colon cancer. On examination, the girl's abdomen is tender to palpation, and there are several small, dark spots on her face and arms.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
- Abdominal pain and diarrhea
- Small, dark spots on the skin (pigmented macules)
- Recurrent respiratory infections
- Family history of colon cancer and Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of recurrent pneumonia over the past year, as well as persistent diarrhea and abdominal pain. She also mentions that she has had multiple episodes of oral thrush and vulvovaginal candidiasis. On examination, the patient has petechiae on her face and arms, and her fingernails are thin and brittle. Family history reveals that her mother died of colon cancer at age 45, and her maternal grandfather had a history of gastric adenocarcinoma. The patient is diagnosed with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS), a rare genetic disorder characterized by pigmented macules on the skin and mucous membranes, as well as a predisposition to various types of cancer, including gastrointestinal, breast, ovarian, and lung cancers. The patient is referred for genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis and discuss management options, including surveillance and risk-reducing surgery.
column17: Patient: A 4-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of rectal bleeding and abdominal pain. He has had recurrent episodes of rectal bleeding over the past year, which have been managed at home by his parents. The patient's medical history is also significant for delayed gross motor development, and he recently underwent a renal ultrasound that showed evidence of kidney damage. Physical examination reveals pigmented macules on the buccal mucosa and perianal area, as well as a large, tender polypoid mass protruding from the rectum. The patient is anemic and has low serum albumin. A diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is suspected based on the combination of GI polyposis, mucocutaneous pigmentation, and family history. Genetic testing confirms a pathogenic variant in the STK11 gene, consistent with PJS. The patient undergoes surgical resection of the rectal polyp, and subsequent surveillance includes regular endoscopies, colonoscopies, and imaging studies to monitor for development of additional polyps or malignancies.
column24: Patient: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of recurrent abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, and anemia. She also mentions that she has had multiple surgeries for removal of polyps in her small intestine since childhood. On physical examination, the patient has dark pigmentation around her mouth, eyes, and nostrils, as well as on her fingers and toes. Her buccal mucosa also shows hyperpigmentation. The patient reports a family history of similar symptoms in her mother and maternal grandfather.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother due to concerns about his growth and development. The mother reports that her son has been experiencing frequent respiratory infections and has had difficulty gaining weight. On examination, the patient is noted to have a short stature, with a height of 3 feet 8 inches (102 cm) and a weight of 46 pounds (20.8 kg). His head circumference is 52 cm. The patient has a distinctive facial appearance, with a prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, and a small jaw. He also has a mild intellectual disability and delayed speech development. The patient's medical history reveals that he was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a history of neonatal jaundice.
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a history of recurrent pneumonia and bronchitis over the past year. He also reports persistent cough, fatigue, and difficulty gaining weight despite a healthy appetite. On examination, he has a prominent forehead, long face, and thin upper lip. His lung examination reveals bilateral crackles and wheezes. The patient's medical history includes a diagnosis of Legius syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the SPRED1 gene.
The most important clinical features for this patient with Legius syndrome include:
Recurrent respiratory infections (pneumonia and bronchitis)
Persistent cough and difficulty gaining weight despite a healthy appetite
Prominent forehead, long face, and thin upper lip (dysmorphic features)
Abnormal lung examination with bilateral crackles and wheezes
Diagnosis of Legius syndrome based on genetic testing.
column17: A 7-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office for his annual well-child visit. His mother mentions that he has had multiple "birthmarks" on his skin since birth, which have been increasing in number and size over time. The boy also has a history of difficulty paying attention in school and has been recently diagnosed with ADHD. On examination, the patient has numerous café-au-lait macules on his trunk, arms, and legs, as well as intertriginous freckling in the axillary and inguinal regions. His head circumference is above the 90th percentile for his age. The boy's growth and development are otherwise normal. The patient's mother also mentions that he has a history of short stature compared to his peers. The pediatrician suspects Legius syndrome and refers the patient to a geneticist for further evaluation and confirmation of the diagnosis.
column24: Ms. J is a 35-year-old woman who presents to the clinic with a lifelong history of multiple café au lait macules. She has never had any neurofibromas or other tumor manifestations. She also reports intertriginous freckling and lipomas. Ms. J has a history of learning disabilities and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and has been on medication for these conditions since childhood. She is short in stature and has a macrocephaly. On physical examination, the patient has numerous café au lait macules on her trunk and extremities, but no Lisch nodules or other signs of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). There are also several lipomas scattered throughout her body. The patient's developmental history reveals that she had some delays in reaching milestones as a child and had difficulty with reading and math in school. She has been seeing a specialist for her learning disabilities and ADHD and has been stable on medication for the past few years. Ms. J is concerned about passing this condition to her children, as she has heard that it can be inherited.

column3: A 4-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, vomiting, and decreased appetite. He appears lethargic and has sunken eyes. His vital signs are temperature 102.5°F (39.7°C), heart rate 120 beats per minute, respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute, blood pressure 80/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals a small boy with a height of 33 inches (84 cm) and weight of 27 pounds (12 kg). He has mild dehydration and moderate hypotonia. There is no evidence of focal neurological deficits or seizure activity. Laboratory studies reveal a serum phosphorus level of 1.5 mg/dL (0.46 mmol/L), alkaline phosphatase level of 120 IU/L (normal range, 100-300 IU/L), and intact parathyroid hormone level of 180 pg/mL (normal range, 15-65 pg/mL). Urinalysis shows proteinuria and pyuria.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a 6-month history of progressive fatigue, bone pain, and difficulty walking. He has a history of smoking and alcohol use disorder but has been sober for the past year. On examination, he has a short stature (157 cm) and a prominent forehead with a prominent jaw. His skin is dry and rough, and he has a thinning of his hair. He has a mild limp when walking. Laboratory tests show a serum phosphate level of 1.8 mg/dL (normal range: 2.5-4.5 mg/dL), alkaline phosphatase level of 120 IU/L (normal range: 40-120 IU/L), and a urinary phosphate excretion of 10 mg/day (normal range: 20-80 mg/day). A radiograph of his left wrist shows evidence of osteomalacia. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the PHEX gene, consistent with X-linked hypophosphatemia.
column17: A 7-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with a 2-year history of progressive bowing of his legs, difficulty walking, and bone pain. He was previously diagnosed with rickets and has been taking vitamin D and calcium supplements without much improvement. On examination, he has short stature (height below the 10th percentile), genu varum, and rachitic rosary. His teeth show signs of abnormal enamel. The patient's medical history reveals a family history of similar symptoms in his older brother. A diagnosis of X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH) is suspected, and further diagnostic tests are ordered to confirm the diagnosis.
column24: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with a long history of musculoskeletal symptoms, including joint pain and stiffness, fractures, and pseudofractures. He also reports short stature, bowed legs, and bone pain that started during childhood. The patient has a history of recurrent abscesses on his teeth and has recently developed hearing loss. On physical examination, the patient has a short stature (150 cm), with bowed legs and genu varum. His skull shows signs of craniosynostosis and there is evidence of previous fractures and pseudofractures. The patient's joints show signs of osteoarthritis, enthesopathy, and muscle weakness. Laboratory tests reveal low serum phosphate levels and high levels of alkaline phosphatase. A genetic test confirms the diagnosis of X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH). The patient is started on phosphate replacement therapy and his symptoms gradually improve over time.

column1: Autosomal dominant optic atrophy, classic form
column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of blurry vision and difficulty seeing in dim lighting environments. He has a positive family history of similar symptoms in his mother and maternal grandfather. On examination, visual acuity is 20/50 in both eyes, and there is a notable decrease in the size of the optic discs. The patient also exhibits nystagmus and strabismus. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of autosomal dominant optic atrophy, classic form.
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of progressive vision loss over the past few years. He has a family history of similar symptoms in his mother and maternal grandfather. On examination, visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes, with a right-sided relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). Funduscopic examination reveals bilateral optic disc pallor and macular edema. Visual field testing shows a central scotoma in both eyes. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of autosomal dominant optic atrophy, classic form.
The most important clinical features for this patient include:

1. Progressive vision loss
2. Family history of similar symptoms
3. Bilateral optic disc pallor
4. Macular edema
5. Central scotoma in both eyes
6. Confirmation of diagnosis through genetic testing.
column17: Patient: 8-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of blurry vision and difficulty seeing colors. He has had trouble seeing the board in class and recognizing objects from a distance. The patient reports that his vision has been gradually worsening over the past year. On examination, visual acuity is 20/80 in both eyes, with a central scotoma. Color vision testing reveals tritanopia. Ophthalmoscopic examination shows temporal pallor of the optic discs and a gray crescent in the neuroretinal rim. The patient's hearing is normal. Family history is negative for similar symptoms.
column24: Ms. J is a 45-year-old woman who presents to the clinic with a long history of gradually worsening vision. She first noticed problems with her vision in her early twenties, when she began having difficulty seeing colors and fine details. Over time, her visual acuity has decreased significantly, and she now struggles to read standard print or recognize faces across the room. Ms. J also reports experiencing difficulty with balance and coordination, particularly in low-light environments. She has a family history of similar vision problems, as her mother and grandmother experienced similar symptoms at a young age. On examination, Ms. J's visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes, with a central scotoma and peripheral field defects. Her color vision is abnormal, with difficulty distinguishing between blue and yellow. Funduscopic examination reveals temporal pallor of the optic discs, with excavation of the left disc. Visual evoked potentials are absent, and pattern electroretinogram shows an abnormal N95:P50 ratio. Ms. J's symptoms and clinical findings are consistent with autosomal dominant optic atrophy, classic form. Genetic testing confirms the presence of a mutation in the OPA1 gene.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with a 2-year history of progressive gait difficulties, frequent falls, and difficulty with fine motor skills such as writing and buttoning his shirt. He also experiences fatigue easily and has a mild cognitive impairment. Examination reveals loss of coordination, ataxic gait, and decreased reflexes in the lower limbs. Family history is positive for a similar condition in an older sibling. The patient's genetic testing reveals a homozygous expansion of a GAA repeat in the first intron of the frataxin gene, consistent with Friedreich ataxia.
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with progressive difficulty walking and performing daily activities over the past year. He has a history of heavy alcohol use but denies any recent significant injuries or illnesses. On examination, he has difficulty standing and walking due to ataxia, dysmetria, and dyskinesia. His speech is slurred, and he has difficulty with fine motor tasks such as writing and buttoning his shirt. He also reports blurred vision and hearing loss. Family history reveals a similar condition in his older sister.
Important clinical features:
Progressive ataxia
Dysmetria
Dyskinesia
Slurred speech
Blurred vision
Hearing loss
column17:
Patient: Sarah, a 10-year-old girl, presents to the clinic with a 2-year history of progressive clumsiness and difficulty walking. She has also noticed difficulty speaking and swallowing, as well as vision loss. Her physical examination reveals dysarthria, ataxia, spasticity in the lower limbs, scoliosis, and absent lower-limb reflexes. Family history is negative for similar symptoms.
Most important clinical features:
* Progressive clumsiness and difficulty walking
* Dysarthria and vision loss
* Spasticity in the lower limbs and scoliosis
* Absent lower-limb reflexes
* Negative family history
These features are consistent with a diagnosis of Friedreich ataxia, a slowly progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by ataxia, dysarthria, muscle weakness, and sensory loss. The presence of spasticity and scoliosis suggests a more advanced stage of the disease. The absence of a positive family history makes it less likely that the condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which is consistent with FRDA.
column24: A 28-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with a 10-year history of progressive gait difficulty, frequent falls, and slurred speech. She also reports gradually worsening muscle weakness, spasticity, and numbness in her lower limbs. On examination, she has a wide, unsteady gait with prominent ataxia, dysarthria, and nystagmus. Her reflexes are absent in the lower limbs, and there is mild scoliosis and pes cavus deformity. She also has mild dysphagia and reports frequent urinary tract infections. Family history reveals a similar condition in her younger brother. The patient's MRI scan shows an atrophy of the cerebellar vermis, and genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Friedreich ataxia.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his parents due to concerns about his facial appearance and difficulty breathing at night. He has a flat nasal bridge, small jaw, and widely spaced eyes. His ears are also abnormally shaped. The patient has a history of frequent ear infections and respiratory problems.
column10: A 35-year-old woman with Treacher-Collins syndrome presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up appointment. She has a history of craniofacial abnormalities, including a small jaw and widely spaced eyes. She also has hearing loss and uses hearing aids. The patient reports experiencing frequent ear infections and difficulty speaking clearly. On examination, the patient's face appears asymmetrical, with a small mandible and prominent ears. Her speech is slurred, and she has difficulty articulating certain sounds. The patient's hearing is assessed using an audiogram, which shows a significant conductive hearing loss.
column17: A three-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother, who is concerned about her son's difficulty swallowing and breathing. The patient has had recurrent respiratory infections and has been using a nasal cannula at night for oxygen supplementation. He also has difficulty articulating words due to a limited mouth opening. On examination, the patient is found to have bilateral downward-slanting palpebral fissures, micrognathia, and external ear abnormalities such as anotia and atresia of the external auditory canals. The patient also has a high palate and cleft palate with a cleft lip. An audiogram reveals bilateral conductive hearing loss. Imaging studies show hypoplasia of the zygomatic bones, mandible, and malar bones. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Treacher Collins syndrome. The patient is referred to a multidisciplinary team for management of his respiratory, feeding, hearing, and dental problems.
column24: A 35 year old woman presents to the clinic with a long history of difficulty swallowing and breathing, which has worsened over the past few years. She also reports that she has had trouble hearing out of her right ear for about 10 years. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have characteristic facial dysmorphism, including bilateral and symmetric downslanting palpebral fissures, malar hypoplasia, micrognathia, and external ear abnormalities such as anotia and atresia of the external auditory canals. The patient also has a high palate and cleft palate with cleft lip. An audiogram reveals conductive hearing loss in the right ear and bilateral choanal stenosis is observed on nasal endoscopy. The patient's intellect is normal, and she reports no history of developmental delays.

column3:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother due to concerns about his growth and development. He was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a low birth weight. His mother reports that he has been growing slowly since birth and is currently below the 5th percentile for height and weight. She also mentions that he has a prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, and a small jaw. The boy's physical examination reveals a number of skin lesions, including multiple keratoses on his hands and feet, as well as a large, raised mole on his lower back. His developmental milestones have been delayed, and he currently has difficulty with speech and language. Family history is positive for a similar condition in his mother and maternal grandfather.
What are the most important clinical features of this patient's presentation?
The most important clinical features of this patient's presentation are:
1. Short stature and low weight for age, indicating growth restriction.
2. Dysmorphic features such as a prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, and small jaw, which are characteristic of Gorlin syndrome.
3. Multiple skin lesions, including keratoses on the hands and feet, and a large, raised mole on the lower back, which are common in patients with Gorlin syndrome.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with multiple skin lesions that have been increasing in number and size over the past few years. He has a history of basal cell carcinoma and has had several skin cancers removed surgically. His physical examination reveals numerous flesh-colored papules and nodules on his face, neck, and arms. Some of the lesions have a characteristic "rice grain" appearance. The patient also reports frequent headaches and has a history of seizures. Family history is significant for his mother having a similar skin condition.
column17: A three-year-old boy presents with a large, firm nodule on his lower back that has been growing over the past year. He also has several small bumps on his face and scalp. His mother mentions that he has had some difficulty swallowing and breathing recently. On examination, the patient is macrocephalic with frontal bossing and coarse facial features. There are multiple 1-3 mm milia on his face, and his eyes appear to be deviated laterally. The nodule on his lower back is firm and immobile. A chest x-ray shows several small calcifications in the falx. The patient's medical history includes a diagnosis of nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (NBCCS). His mother has a similar appearance and history, as well as a history of basal cell carcinomas. The patient is referred for an MRI of the brain and spine to evaluate for medulloblastoma, as well as for genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis of NBCCS.
column24: A 35-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a 2-year history of multiple skin lesions on his face, back, and chest. He also reports having had several bone tumors removed surgically over the past decade. On examination, he has coarse facial features, frontal bossing, and macrocephaly. There are multiple keratosystic odontogenic cysts in his mandible. His skin lesions include numerous basal cell carcinomas and squamous cell carcinomas. He also has palmar pits and skeletal anomalies including bifid ribs and wedge-shaped vertebrae. A review of systems reveals no history of seizures or neurological symptoms. Family history is unremarkable. Genetic testing reveals a pathogenic variant in the PTCH1 gene, consistent with a diagnosis of Gorlin syndrome. The patient is referred to a multidisciplinary team for further management and surveillance.

column3: A 4-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office for a routine well-child visit. Her parents report that she has been having some difficulty with speech and language development, and they are concerned about her cognitive abilities. On examination, the child appears small for her age and has a distinctive facial appearance, with a broad forehead, widely spaced eyes, and a short upturned nose. She also has a small head circumference and short stature. The child is unable to speak in full sentences and has difficulty following simple commands. A chromosomal analysis reveals a deletion of genetic material on chromosome 4p, consistent with Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.
column10: A 35-year-old woman with Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome presents to the clinic with her caregiver. She has a history of developmental delay, intellectual disability, and seizures. On examination, she has a distinctive facial appearance with a small head, narrow eyes, and a short nose. She also has short stature, microcephaly, and a single crease in her palmar surface. Her speech is limited to a few words, and she has difficulty walking independently due to muscle weakness. The patient has a history of recurrent respiratory infections and has recently been diagnosed with sleep apnea.
column17: A 3-year-old girl named Lily presents to the clinic with her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's developmental delay and seizures. Lily was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a birth weight of 2.5 kg. She has been experiencing recurrent respiratory tract infections and otitis media since she was 6 months old. Her mother reports that Lily has difficulty feeding herself, is not yet potty trained, and cannot walk independently. On examination, Lily's facial features are consistent with Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome, including a broad nasal bridge, high forehead, and short philtrum. She also has microcephaly, kyphosis, and clubfeet. Lily is hypotonic and has difficulty sitting up without support. Her speech is limited to a few words and sounds. The patient's seizures started when she was 6 months old and have been triggered by fever. She has had multiple episodes of status epilepticus, and her electroencephalogram (EEG) shows spikes in the left hemisphere. Lily's developmental delay is severe, with no sphincter control, self-feeding, or dressing skills. Her intellectual disability is moderate to severe, and she has limited speech ability.
column24: A 25-year-old woman with Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up appointment. She has a distinctive facial appearance, including a broad nasal bridge, high forehead, and short philtrum. She has a history of intellectual disability, developmental delay, and seizures that began in infancy and have continued throughout her life. She has limited speech and uses simple sentences to communicate. She has difficulty with self-feeding and dressing and requires assistance with daily living activities. She has a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections and otitis media, and has been diagnosed with a congenital heart defect. Her physical examination reveals hypotonia, clubfeet, and split hand. Imaging studies have shown structural central nervous system defects, including thinning of the corpus callosum. Despite these challenges, she is friendly and engaging, and has a strong support system from her family and caregivers. The most important clinical features for this patient include her distinctive facial appearance, intellectual disability, developmental delay, seizures, and congenital heart defect.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He has not been able to keep anything down, including fluids. He appears pale and sweaty, and his abdomen is tender to palpation. His liver and spleen are enlarged. Laboratory tests reveal a high level of triglycerides in the blood, and a low level of HDL cholesterol. The patient's condition worsens rapidly, and he becomes unresponsive and hypotensive.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal pain. He has a history of recurrent pancreatitis and has been diagnosed with Lysosomal acid lipase deficiency (LAL-D). On examination, he has a prominent abdomen and signs of malnutrition. His liver function tests are elevated, and his serum triglycerides are 10 times the upper limit of normal. He is referred to a specialist for further management.
column17: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. He has had recurrent episodes of similar symptoms over the past year, which have been managed at home without improvement. On examination, he appears pale and wasted, with a prominent abdomen and enlarged liver. His weight is below the 10th percentile for his age, and he has difficulty walking due to weakness. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver transaminases. A lipid profile shows markedly elevated LDL-cholesterol and triglycerides. Imaging studies demonstrate hepatomegaly with heterogeneous liver parenchyma and mild splenomegaly. The diagnosis of lysosomal acid lipase deficiency is suspected, and the patient is referred for further evaluation and management.
column24: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of persistent fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and difficulty losing weight despite a recent change in diet and exercise routine. He also mentions experiencing intermittent episodes of vomiting and diarrhea over the past year. Physical examination reveals a soft, non-tender abdomen with mild hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertriglyceridemia. A lipid profile demonstrates markedly reduced HDL-C levels. The patient is referred to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation, and a liver biopsy reveals accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in hepatocytes, consistent with lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) deficiency. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis, identifying two pathogenic variants in the LIPA gene. The patient is initiated on a trial of enzyme replacement therapy and referred to a specialized lipid clinic for management of dyslipidemia.

column3:
A 3-year-old boy, John, presents to the clinic with his mother due to concerns about his growth and development. He was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a birth weight of 2.8 kg. His mother reports that he has always been small for his age and has difficulty reaching milestones. On examination, John's height is below the 10th percentile, and he has a short thorax and long limbs. His facial features include a prominent forehead, narrow eyes, and a small jaw. He also has clinodactyly (curved fifth fingers) and mild developmental delay. John's genetic testing reveals a mutation in the HMX3 gene, consistent with Campomelic dysplasia.
The most important clinical features of this patient with Campomelic dysplasia include:
1. Short stature and growth restriction
2. Skeletal abnormalities (e.g., short thorax, long limbs)
3. Facial dysmorphism (e.g., prominent forehead, narrow eyes, small jaw)
4. Clinodactyly (curved fifth fingers)
5. Developmental delay
6. Genetic mutation in the HMX3 gene.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the office with a known diagnosis of Campomelic dysplasia, a rare genetic disorder that affects bone development. He has short stature and characteristic physical features such as a small jaw, prominent forehead, and short limbs. He also experiences chronic joint pain and limited mobility due to degenerative joint disease. The patient is concerned about the progression of his condition and wants to discuss treatment options to improve his quality of life.
column17: A 3-month-old baby boy was brought to the clinic by his parents due to concerns regarding his breathing and feeding difficulties. The baby was born at term, but had required oxygen therapy and suctioning of the oropharynx since birth. On examination, the baby had a large head, a flat face, a cleft palate, and a short neck. His chest was sunken, and he had difficulty breathing. He also had clubfeet and dislocated hips. The baby's genitalia were ambiguous, with a small phallus and a notched scrotum. The parents reported that the baby had been making stridor sounds while breathing and had difficulty feeding due to a weak suck reflex. Further evaluation revealed that the baby had laryngotracheomalacia and respiratory distress, and an X-ray of his limbs showed bowing of the femora and tibiae. A karyotype analysis revealed a 46,XY chromosomal complement. The clinical features were consistent with a diagnosis of Campomelic dysplasia.
column24: John Doe is a 30-year-old male who presents to the clinic with a known diagnosis of Campomelic dysplasia (CD). He was born with a cleft palate and Pierre Robin sequence, which led to respiratory compromise in the neonatal period. John had undergone several surgeries for his cleft palate and respiratory issues during his childhood. He also has clubfeet and short bowed femurs and tibias, which have caused him to walk with a cane since he was a child. Despite these challenges, John has been able to live an independent life and work as an accountant. However, over the past year, he has noticed progressive shortness of breath and fatigue, which have made it difficult for him to perform his job. He also reports hearing impairment and neck pain. Physical examination reveals a small head, flat face, and laryngotracheomalacia. His height is 4 feet 5 inches, and he has a short stature. John's spine is curved in a kyphoscoliosis manner, and his lower limbs are bowed. He also has skin dimples on his pretibial area.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with lethargy, poor appetite, and vomiting after eating protein-rich foods. He has a history of developmental delay and seizures. Physical examination reveals a thin, pale child with a heightened reflexive response to stimuli. Laboratory tests show an increased levels of ammonia in the blood. The patient is diagnosed with Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency, a urea cycle disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamylase. This results in an accumulation of ammonia in the bloodstream, leading to the clinical features described above.
