column17: A 5-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his concerned mother, who mentions that her son has had difficulty growing hair since birth. The boy also has very thick and brittle nails, which have led to recurrent paronychial infections. Additionally, he has hyperpigmentation over his joints and bony prominences. On examination, the patient is found to have partial alopecia, dystrophic nails, and palmoplantar hyperkeratosis. These clinical features are consistent with a diagnosis of Hidrotic ectodermal dysplasia (HED2 or Clouston syndrome). The most important clinical features in this case include the triad of alopecia, nail dystrophy, and palmoplantar hyperkeratosis.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a lifelong history of sparse hair growth, nail abnormalities, and thickened skin on her palms and soles. She has never had a full head of hair and has noticed progressive hair loss over the years, leaving her with thinning scalp hair and absent eyebrows and eyelashes. Her nails are thick, brittle, and prone to infection. She also experiences painful calluses on her palms and soles, which have become more severe with age. The patient is concerned about the impact of these symptoms on her appearance and quality of life. Physical examination reveals a tall, slender woman with a prominent forehead, thinning scalp hair, and absent eyebrows and eyelashes. Her nails are thickened, hyperconvex, and discolored, and she has palmoplantar hyperkeratosis with calluses on her palms and soles. The patient's teeth are normal, and there is no evidence of dental anomalies. A diagnosis of Hidrotic ectodermal dysplasia 2 (HED2) is suspected based on the patient's clinical features, and genetic testing is recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of vomiting, diarrhea, and lethargy. The patient has a history of developmental delay and has been followed by a pediatrician for concerns regarding his speech and gross motor skills. On examination, the patient is afebrile but appears dehydrated. His blood work reveals an elevated aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT). The patient's urine output, protein intake, and lipid profiles are consistent with nephrotic syndrome. A kidney biopsy shows mesangial immune deposits and fibrosis, consistent with membranous nephropathy. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the NPHS1 gene, diagnostic of Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a 2-year history of progressive muscle weakness and wasting, particularly in his legs. He also reports frequent falls and difficulty ambulating. The patient has a history of cognitive decline, memory loss, and seizures. On physical examination, the patient has marked muscle atrophy, weakness, and spasticity. Laboratory tests reveal very high levels of carnitine in his blood, and a genetic test confirms a diagnosis of Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency.
column17: A 10-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe muscle pain and weakness after participating in a school physical fitness test. He had a similar episode last year but it resolved on its own. His parents mention that he often gets muscle cramps when running long distances. The patient appears pale and sweaty, with signs of dehydration. On examination, there is no tenderness to palpation over the major muscle groups, but there is a mild elevation in serum creatine kinase (CK) levels. Further investigation reveals a low carnitine level and high levels of acylcarnitines in the blood. A diagnosis of Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II (CPT II) deficiency is suspected, and the patient is started on supplementation with L-carnitine and medium-chain triglycerides (MCT). After a few weeks of treatment, the patient reports significant improvement in muscle symptoms and is able to participate in physical activities without issues. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of CPT II deficiency.
column24: Patient: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe muscle pain and weakness after running a marathon. He has a history of similar episodes following strenuous exercise, but never this severe. He also reports recent viral symptoms. On examination, he has marked muscle tenderness and swelling, particularly in the legs. His CK level is elevated at 10,000 IU/L, and his urine output is high. Genetic testing reveals a compound heterozygote mutation in the CPT II gene, consistent with the myopathic form of Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He appears lethargic and has difficulty walking due to severe lower back pain. His parents report that he has had several episodes of constipation over the past year, and they have noticed some blood in his stool. On examination, the patient's vital signs are normal except for a temperature of 102°F (39°C). Abdominal examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the lower back with guarding and rigidity. The patient is unable to walk or stand without support.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute severe abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. She has a history of intermittent abdominal pain over the past year but never as severe as this episode. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, with guarding and rebound tenderness. The patient appears uncomfortable and distressed.
column17: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, vomiting and abdominal pain. He was born at term without any notable prenatal or perinatal issues. His parents mention that he has had recurrent constipation and soiling accidents for the past year. On examination, his vital signs are normal except for a temperature of 39°C. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the lower abdomen with no guarding or rebound tenderness. There is no surgical emergency, and he can go home on antibiotics and stool softeners. Further workup is planned for the next few days.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening lower back pain, fever, and difficulty ambulating. She has a history of constipation and urinary incontinence. Physical examination reveals a sacral dimple, and imaging studies show a presacral mass and an abnormality in the shape of the sacrum. Further workup reveals a diagnosis of Currarino syndrome, with a meningocoele and a tethered spinal cord. The patient undergoes surgical intervention to relieve pressure on the spinal cord and repair the meningocoele. Follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor for potential malignant transformation and to address any ongoing bowel or bladder issues.

column3: A 6-month-old boy, who was born to healthy non-consanguineous parents, presents with a large head, macrocephaly, and an abnormal neurological examination. He has a weak cry, poor sucking reflex, and is unable to lift his head while prone. The patient also has developmental delay, hypotonia, and seizures. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the ASPA gene, consistent with Canavan disease.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 6-month history of progressive weakness and loss of motor skills. She has difficulty walking, speaking, and swallowing. She also reports recurrent seizures and vision loss. On examination, she has spasticity, ataxia, and cognitive impairment. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the ASPA gene, consistent with Canavan disease.
column17: A 3-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his concerned parents, who report that their son has been experiencing increasing difficulty with walking and speaking over the past year. The boy was previously developmentally normal, but now struggles to communicate in full sentences and often falls when trying to stand or walk. He also appears to have a larger-than-normal head size. On examination, the boy's speech is slurred and he has difficulty following simple commands. His muscle tone is decreased, leading to a "floppy" appearance of his limbs. The boy's head circumference is measured at 52 cm, which is well above the 90th percentile for his age. Laboratory tests reveal a significantly elevated concentration of N-acetyl-L-aspartic acid (NAA) in his urine and blood. An MRI scan shows abnormal signal intensity in the brain, consistent with leukodystrophy. The patient is diagnosed with Canavan disease, a rare genetic disorder that affects the brain and spinal cord.
column24: Ms. J is a 27-year-old woman who presents to the neurology clinic with a long history of developmental delays, macrocephaly, and progressive cognitive decline. She was diagnosed with Canavan disease as an infant based on elevated N-acetyl-L-aspartic acid (NAA) levels in her urine and cerebrospinal fluid. Despite early interventions and therapies, Ms. J's cognitive and motor skills have continued to deteriorate over the years. She has difficulty with speech, walking, and performing daily activities. Her head circumference is increased, and she has a distinctive facial appearance with a prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, and a small jaw. Ms. J's medical history includes seizures, sleep disturbances, and recurrent respiratory infections. She has also experienced progressive loss of vision and hearing. The patient's condition has significantly impacted her quality of life, and she is now seeking further evaluation and management options to address her symptoms and improve her overall well-being.

column3:
A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with acute pancreatitis. He has a history of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and has been diagnosed with familial chylomicronemia syndrome (FCS). His lipemic serum is positive for chylomicrons, and genetic testing reveals a mutation in the LIPA gene. The most important clinical features include:
Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and fever.
Elevated triglycerides levels (>1000 mg/dL) and low HDL-C levels (<30mg/dL).
Presence of chylomicrons in the blood.
Family history of FCS or other lipid disorders.
Pancreatitis, which can be acute or chronic.
column10:
A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He has a history of recurrent pancreatitis and has been diagnosed with Familial chylomicronemia syndrome (FCS). His lipemic serum is positive for chylomicrons. He is currently taking lipid-lowering medications but has not been adherent to his treatment regimen. On examination, he has tenderness in the abdomen with guarding and rebound tenderness. His blood work shows elevated triglycerides, and a lipemic serum is positive for chylomicrons.
The most important clinical features of this scenario are:
1. Severe abdominal pain
2. History of recurrent pancreatitis
3. Diagnosis of Familial chylomicronemia syndrome (FCS)
4. Lipemic serum positive for chylomicrons
5. Elevated triglycerides
6. Non-adherence to lipid-lowering medications.
column17: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to persistent vomiting and abdominal pain over the past week. The baby has been failing to gain weight appropriately, and his parents have noticed a change in his appetite and behavior recently. On examination, the patient appears tired and irritable, with sunken eyes and a pale, cool, and clammy skin. His abdomen is distended, and there is a palpable liver edge. The patient has lipemia retinalis, and his serum triglyceride levels are markedly elevated (>10 mmol/L or >875 mg/dL). The diagnosis of familial chylomicronemia syndrome is suspected, and further genetic testing will be needed to confirm the diagnosis.
column24: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. She has a history of recurrent pancreatitis attacks and has been diagnosed with Familial Chylomicronemia Syndrome (FCS). On examination, she has signs of dehydration, tachycardia and tender abdomen. Her lipids profile reveals severely elevated triglycerides (>10 mmol/L or >875 mg/dL) and low HDL-C. She is admitted for intravenous fluids, pain management and further workup.

column3:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever. He has a history of similar episodes in the past, which have been diagnosed as stomach flu. However, this time, his symptoms are more severe, and he appears pale and clammy. On examination, his vital signs are normal except for a temperature of 102°F (39°C). His abdomen is tender to palpation, with guarding and rebound tenderness. The patient has a family history of Autosomal erythropoietic protoporphyria (AEP), a rare genetic disorder that affects the production of heme, a component of hemoglobin.
The most important clinical features of this case are:
1. Severe abdominal pain
2. Vomiting
3. Fever
4. Pale and clammy appearance
5. Tender and guarded abdomen
6. Family history of AEP
7. Previous similar episodes
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a long history of recurring abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, which worsens during sun exposure. He also reports experiencing fatigue, weakness, and dark urine. Physical examination reveals jaundice, and laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes, haemolytic anemia, and low levels of porphyrins in the urine. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Autosomal erythropoietic protoporphyria (AEP).
The most important clinical features for this patient with AEP include:
1. Recurring abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, which worsens during sun exposure.
2. Fatigue and weakness.
3. Jaundice.
4. Haemolytic anemia.
5. Low levels of porphyrins in the urine.
6. Confirmation of the diagnosis through genetic testing.
column17: Patient: 4-year-old girl who presents to the emergency department with her mother due to severe pain and redness on her face, arms, and legs after spending a few hours playing outside on a sunny day. The patient has had similar episodes in the past but never this severe. Physical examination reveals erythema, edema, and petechiae on sun-exposed areas of her skin, along with signs of liver dysfunction (mild elevations of liver enzymes). No blistering or scarring is observed. The patient has a family history of similar symptoms in her older siblings. Laboratory tests show increased levels of porphyrins and lipiduria. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of autosomal erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP).
column24: Patient: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a history of severe skin pain and burning sensations after sun exposure, which has been worsening over the past few years. She reports that her symptoms begin within 30 minutes of sun exposure and can last for several hours. She also notices swelling and redness on her face, arms, and legs after sun exposure. The patient has a history of similar symptoms in childhood but they have become more severe in adulthood. Physical examination reveals lichenification, leathery pseudovesicles, and grooving around the lips, as well as loss of lunulae on her fingernails. The patient also reports mild elevations of liver enzymes and occasional episodes of acute liver disease. Family history is negative for similar symptoms.

column3:
A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. He has had a fever for the past day and appears lethargic. On examination, he has signs of dehydration, including dry mucous membranes and decreased urine output. His abdomen is tender to palpation, and there is a suspicion of an acute abdomen. The patient has a history of Tyrosinemia type 1, a rare genetic disorder that affects the metabolism of the amino acid tyrosine. He has been adherent to his medication regimen but has recently been experiencing worsening abdominal symptoms.
Important clinical features:
-Tyrosinemia type 1 diagnosis
-Vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain
-Fever and dehydration
-Tender abdomen
-History of adherence to medication regimen but worsening symptoms.
column10:
A 34-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea. He also mentions that he has been experiencing fatigue, weight loss, and a rash on his palms and soles. On physical examination, the patient appears thin and wasted, with signs of dehydration. His abdomen is tender to palpation, and he has a maculopapular rash on his palms and soles. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated tyrosine level in his blood, and a diagnosis of Tyrosinemia type 1 is suspected.
The most important clinical features for this patient include:
* Abdominal pain and diarrhea
* Fatigue and weight loss
* Maculopapular rash on the palms and soles
* Elevated tyrosine level in the blood
* Suspicion of Tyrosinemia type 1
column17:
A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of abdominal pain, vomiting, and constipation. He has a history of growth failure and rickets. On examination, he has a large liver and spleen, and signs of peripheral neuropathy. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes, hypoglycemia, and metabolic acidosis. A diagnosis of tyrosinemia type 1 is suspected, and the child is started on nitisinone and a low-tyrosine diet. Further workup reveals evidence of chronic liver disease, including cirrhosis and portal hypertension, as well as renal tubular dysfunction. The child's neurological symptoms improve with treatment, but close follow-up is necessary to monitor for potential recurrence of neurological crises and hepatocellular carcinoma. Important clinical features include: 

1. Severe liver involvement, including cirrhosis and portal hypertension
2. Renal tubular dysfunction
3. Growth failure and rickets
4. Neurological symptoms, including abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy
column24: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss over the past six months. He also reports a history of recurrent neurological crises, characterized by severe abdominal pain, autonomic dysfunction, and respiratory decompensation, which have been managed with hospitalizations and supportive care. The patient has a history of liver disease and rickets, and was diagnosed with Tyrosinemia type 1 as an infant. He has been non-adherent to treatment and follow-up appointments for many years. On examination, the patient appears cachectic and has marked hepatomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes, hypersplenism, and renal tubular dysfunction. Imaging studies show cirrhosis and nodules concerning for HCC. The patient is referred to a specialist and started on nitisinone and a low-tyrosine diet, with plans for close monitoring and follow-up to prevent further complications.

column3:
A 7-year-old boy named Max presents to the clinic with his mother due to concerns about his facial appearance and difficulty breathing through his nose. Max has a prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, and a short, upturned nose. He also has a history of recurrent ear infections and hearing loss. His mother reports that he often breathes through his mouth and snores at night.
The most important clinical features for this patient with Crouzon syndrome include:
Prominent forehead
Widely spaced eyes
Short, upturned nose
Recurrent ear infections
Hearing loss
Mouth breathing
Snoring at night
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a long history of difficulty breathing through her nose, nasal congestion, and recurrent sinus infections. She has a characteristic "boxer's" nose deformity and widely spaced eyes. Her intelligence is normal, but she has a mild learning disability.
column17: A 2-year-old boy presents with a prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes (ocular hypertelorism), a small beaked nose, and protruding eyes (exophthalmos). His parents are concerned about his breathing and feeding difficulties. Physical examination reveals hypoplastic maxilla and mandibular prognathism. The child has a history of recurrent respiratory infections and has recently developed a squint. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema. Imaging studies (CT or MRI) show craniosynostosis involving multiple sutures, hydrocephaly, descent of the cerebellar tonsils, and anomalies in jugular venous drainage. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Crouzon syndrome. The child is referred for neurosurgical evaluation and management of intracranial hypertension to prevent blindness.
column24: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with a long history of progressive headaches and blurred vision. He was diagnosed with Crouzon syndrome as a child and has been followed by multiple specialists for his condition. On examination, he has a prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, a short nose, and a protruding jaw. His neurological examination reveals papilledema (swelling of the optic disc) and decreased peripheral vision. Imaging studies show hydrocephaly (fluid accumulation in the brain) and descent of the cerebellar tonsils. The patient is referred for surgical intervention to relieve intracranial pressure and prevent further visual loss. The most important clinical features in this case are the presence of papilledema, decreased peripheral vision, hydrocephaly, and descent of the cerebellar tonsils, all of which are indicative of Crouzon syndrome and its associated complications.

column3:
A 10-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office with her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's lack of pubertal development. The girl has always had a flat chest and has not started menstruating yet. She also has a high-pitched voice and sparse body hair. On examination, the patient has a normal female external genitalia, but there is no evidence of pubertal changes such as breast development or axillary hair growth. The patient's height and weight are at the 50th percentile for her age.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
- Lack of pubertal development
- Normal female external genitalia
- High-pitched voice
- Sparse body hair
- No evidence of breast development or axillary hair growth.
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to the endocrinology clinic with a history of infertility, small testes, and a lack of facial and body hair. He was raised as a girl until puberty, when he began to identify as male. He has never had a period and has always had a low libido. Physical examination reveals a tall, slender man with a high-pitched voice, small testes, and no visible body hair. Laboratory tests show a total testosterone level of 200 ng/dL and a free testosterone level of 50 pg/mL.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
* Infertility
* Small testes
* Lack of facial and body hair
* High-pitched voice
* Low libido
* Abnormal hormone levels (low total testosterone and low free testosterone)
These features suggest a diagnosis of complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS), which is a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of male reproductive organs and secondary sex characteristics. The patient's history of being raised as a girl until puberty and his lack of facial and body hair are also important clues to the diagnosis.
column17: A 10-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office with her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's lack of breast development and absence of menstruation. The girl has normal female external genitalia but no signs of pubertal development. Physical examination reveals a tall stature, normal female breasts, and absence of axillary and pubic hair. There is no evidence of any masculinization of the external genitalia. Family history reveals that her older sister had a similar presentation at puberty and was diagnosed with complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS). The patient's karyotype is 46,XY, and hormone levels show normal female levels of estradiol and low testosterone. A pelvic ultrasound reveals the presence of a testis in the inguinal canal. The patient is diagnosed with CAIS, and genetic counseling is offered to the family.
column24: A 30-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a complaint of amenorrhea since menarche. She has always identified as female, and her physical examination reveals normal female external genitalia, including breasts and female adiposity. However, on further questioning, she mentions that she has never had much body hair and has always felt tall compared to her peers. Her family history is significant for an older sister who had an inguinal hernia repair in childhood. The patient's karyotype reveals a 46,XY genotype, and imaging studies demonstrate the presence of testes in the inguinal canals. The patient is diagnosed with complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS).

column3: A 3-year-old boy named Max presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother due to concerns about his growth and development. Max was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a birth weight of 2.8 kg. His mother reports that he has been growing slowly since birth and is currently below the 10th percentile for height and weight on the growth charts. She also mentions that Max has a distinctive facial appearance, with a prominent forehead, deep-set eyes, and a small pointed chin. Additionally, Max has a history of neonatal jaundice and has been diagnosed with mild intellectual disability. During the physical examination, the pediatrician notes that Max has a prominent abdominal bump and a large, flat nasal bridge. The pediatrician suspects that Max may have Alagille syndrome and refers him for further diagnostic testing.
column10: A 35-year-old woman with Alagille syndrome presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, nausea, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain. She has a history of heart disease and has been diagnosed with liver cirrhosis. On examination, her vital signs are normal except for a temperature of 100.4°F (38°C). Her abdomen is tender to palpation in the right upper quadrant, and she has evidence of neuropathy. Laboratory studies reveal an elevated white blood cell count, elevated liver enzymes, and a positive viral load.
column17: A 3-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother, who is concerned about her son's persistent jaundice and "yellow" eyes. The child has had a history of prolonged jaundice since birth, which has not resolved despite phototherapy. Physical examination reveals a prominent forehead, deep-set eyes, upslanting palpebral fissures, hypertelorism, flat nasal root, and pointed chin. The child also has hepatosplenomegaly, and there is a cardiac murmur heard on auscultation. Laboratory tests show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and coagulopathy. A liver biopsy shows bile duct paucity. An echocardiogram reveals pulmonary atresia with a ventricular septal defect. The child is diagnosed with Alagille syndrome, and further evaluation shows growth delay, fat malabsorption, and mild developmental delay. The mother reports that the child has been experiencing pruritus and has developed xanthomas on his hands and feet. The child is referred to a specialist for further management of his liver and cardiac disease.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician's office for a routine checkup. She has a history of Alagille syndrome, a multisystem disorder that affects the liver, heart, kidneys, and other systems. The patient reports experiencing persistent fatigue, itching all over her body, and abdominal discomfort after eating fatty foods. She also mentions that she has been having trouble seeing at night and notices that her vision is getting worse. On physical examination, the patient's liver and spleen are enlarged, and she has a characteristic facial appearance with a prominent forehead, deep-set eyes, and a pointed chin. The patient's cardiac examination reveals a heart murmur, and her abdominal examination shows tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertriglyceridemia. Imaging studies, such as ultrasound or CT scans, may be ordered to evaluate the liver, kidneys, and cardiac structures. Genetic testing can also help confirm the diagnosis of Alagille syndrome. The patient's symptoms and clinical features are consistent with the spectrum of manifestations seen in Alagille syndrome.

column1: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase deficiency
column3: A 3-year-old girl presents with ambiguous genitalia, a large clitoris, and fused labia. She has a short stature and delayed pubertal development. The patient also experiences early adrenarche, including pubic hair and axillary hair. Family history reveals a similar condition in an older sibling.
column10:
A 27-year-old woman presents to the endocrinology clinic with a history of vague symptoms, including fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal pain. She was born with ambiguous genitalia and was raised as a male until puberty, when she began to identify as female. Her physical examination reveals a tall, thin woman with a prominent forehead, a small jaw, and a flat chest. She has a low-pitched voice and a sparse beard. The patient's laboratory results show a high level of 17-hydroxyprogesterone and a low level of cortisol.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
* Ambiguous genitalia at birth
* Raised as a male until puberty
* Identifies as female
* Tall, thin build
* Prominent forehead
* Small jaw
* Flat chest
* Low-pitched voice
* Sparse beard
* High level of 17-hydroxyprogesterone
* Low level of cortisol.
column17: A 3-month-old girl presents to the emergency department with ambiguous genitalia, failure to thrive, and hypoglycemia. She was born at home with a birth weight of 2.8 kg and had not been gaining weight appropriately. On examination, she has a prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes, and a small jaw. Genital examination reveals a large clitoris and fused labia. The child is lethargic and has poor feeding. Laboratory tests show low cortisol levels, high 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels, and normal 11-deoxycortisol levels. Chromosomal analysis reveals a 46,XX karyotype. The patient is diagnosed with cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase deficiency (PORD), a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Treatment includes glucocorticoid replacement, and surgical correction of the genital abnormalities.
column24: A 32-year-old woman presents to the endocrinology clinic with a history of irregular menses, hirsutism, and infertility. She was born with ambiguous genitalia and raised as a male until puberty when she developed breast tissue and started menstruating. Her physical examination reveals a tall stature, acne, and excessive body hair. Laboratory tests show low cortisol levels, high 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels, and normal 11-deoxycorticosterone levels. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase deficiency (PORD). The patient is started on glucocorticoid replacement therapy, spironolactone for hirsutism, and fertility treatment with gonadotropins. She eventually conceives and delivers a healthy baby boy but requires continued hormone replacement and monitoring for potential complications related to her PORD deficiency.

column1: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency
column3: A 3-year-old girl presents with ambiguous genitalia, failure to grow and develop secondary sexual characteristics, and a recent diagnosis of simple virilizing congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency. She has a high-pitched voice, no pubic hair, and a small clitoris. Her growth rate is below the third percentile, and bone age is 2 years behind her chronological age. The most important clinical features in this scenario are ambiguous genitalia, failure to grow and develop secondary sexual characteristics, high-pitched voice, no pubic hair, small clitoris, below the third percentile growth rate, and bone age 2 years behind her chronological age. These features suggest a diagnosis of simple virilizing congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency.
column10:
A 25-year-old woman presents to the endocrinology clinic with a history of easy bruising, fatigue, and recent weight gain. She was diagnosed with Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) as an infant and has been on hydrocortisone replacement therapy since then. Her current medication regimen includes 20 mg of hydrocortisone in the morning and 10 mg at night. She has never had a surgical intervention for her condition. On examination, her blood pressure is 98/60 mmHg, heart rate 75 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and body mass index (BMI) 28 kg/m2. She has a small frame and appears to have some facial hair. Her adrenal glands are not palpable. Laboratory tests show:
Serum cortisol: 30 nmol/L (normal range, 150-400 nmol/L)
Serum aldosterone: 80 pmol/L (normal range, 100-1000 pmol/L)
Urinary free cortisol: 24 nmol/day (normal range, 20-100 nmol/day)
column17: Patient: A 4-year-old girl named Sophia presents to the clinic with her mother due to concerns about her growth and development. Sophia was born at term without any complications, but her mother noticed that she has been growing much faster than her peers. She also mentions that Sophia has been experiencing frequent nosebleeds and bruising easily. On examination, Sophia's blood pressure is elevated, and she has a masculinized appearance with a deep voice, clitoromegaly, and a prominent jaw. Her growth chart reveals that she has accelerated growth velocity and advanced bone age. Laboratory tests show low cortisol levels and high 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels, confirming the diagnosis of 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency CAH.
column24: Patient: A 35-year-old woman presents to the endocrinology clinic with a history of easy bruising, weight gain, and fatigue. She also reports that she has had irregular periods for several years. On physical examination, she has a prominent jawline, a deep voice, and excessive body hair growth on her face, chest, and back. Her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone and low levels of cortisol. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency, a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).

column3:
Max, who is six years old, has been experiencing pain in his legs and difficulty walking for the past year. His bones have gradually hardened and grown thicker over time, giving them a characteristic spongy texture on X-rays. Due to his fragile bones, Max has experienced multiple fractures from minor falls. He also experiences frequent headaches and nausea due to the pressure of the excessive bone growth on his brain and other organs.
Max's medical history reveals that he has a family history of similar symptoms in both his siblings and parents, indicating that the condition is inherited. His physical examination reveals a characteristic hunched posture due to the weight of his heavy bones, as well as limited mobility and dexterity.
Max's vignette highlights the most important clinical features of Autosomal recessive malignant osteopetrosis, such as excessive bone growth, bone fragility, headaches, nausea, and a family history of similar symptoms.
column10: Meet Sarah, a 35-year-old woman who has been experiencing progressive bone pain, weakness, and fatigue for the past year. She has also noticed an increasing number of fractures, particularly in her legs and hips, which have not healed properly despite prolonged immobilization. Sarah's medical history includes a childhood diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), a genetic disorder that affects bone formation and increases the risk of fractures. However, her symptoms have worsened significantly over the past year, prompting her to seek further evaluation.Physical examination reveals a thin, frail woman with a prominent forehead, long face, and protruding eyes. Sarah has a significant limp and is unable to walk without assistance. Her bones appear abnormally large and dense, with visible deformities in her legs and hips.
column17: Patient Vignette: Meet Emily, a 2-year-old girl who was born with Autosomal Recessive Malignant Osteopetrosis (ARO). Emily's parents noticed that she was not growing at the same rate as her siblings and that her head seemed misshapen. Upon further evaluation, it was discovered that Emily had a rare genetic disorder that affected her bone development. She had fractures in multiple bones, including her skull, which led to optic nerve compression and hearing loss. Emily also experienced seizures due to hypocalcemia and had a high risk of developing mandibular osteomyelitis. Despite the challenges that come with this condition, Emily's parents are determined to provide her with the best possible care and quality of life. They work closely with her healthcare team to manage her symptoms and ensure that she receives regular monitoring and treatment for her bone health.
column24: Ms. Smith is a 35-year-old woman who presents to our office with a history of recurrent fractures and progressive vision loss since childhood. She has had multiple fractures of her limbs, ribs, and spine, which have been managed with casts and braces. Despite this, she has experienced persistent pain and limited mobility in her lower extremities. Recently, she has noticed worsening blurred vision and double vision, which has made it difficult for her to work as a graphic designer. On examination, Ms. Smith's visual acuity is 20/200 in both eyes, with evidence of optic nerve compression. She also has a significant hearing loss and facial weakness on the left side. Her skull shows evidence of sclerosis at the base, and her bone marrow aspirate shows features consistent with malignant osteopetrosis. Ms. Smith's laboratory studies reveal severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hypocalcemia. She is diagnosed with autosomal recessive malignant osteopetrosis (ARO), a rare genetic disorder that affects bone development and remodeling, leading to bone fragility, fractures, and vision loss due to optic nerve compression.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 2-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother, who is concerned about her son's developmental delay and frequent falls. The boy was born at term and had a normal birth weight, but he has not been able to sit up or walk on his own yet. He also has difficulty with swallowing and often chokes on his food. Physical examination reveals a child with a large head, prominent forehead, and widely spaced eyes. His muscle tone is decreased, and he has difficulty keeping his balance. The boy's developmental milestones are significantly delayed, and he does not respond to his name or make eye contact. Laboratory tests show a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A, confirming the diagnosis of GM1 gangliosidosis.
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with a 2-year history of progressive difficulty walking, balance problems, and frequent falls. He also reports numbness and tingling sensations in his hands and feet. On examination, he has a wide, unsteady gait, and his reflexes are diminished. His cognitive function is normal. Family history reveals that his mother and maternal grandfather had similar symptoms at a similar age.
The most important clinical features of this patient vignette are:
Progressive difficulty walking and balance problems
Frequent falls
Numbness and tingling sensations in hands and feet
Wide, unsteady gait
Diminished reflexes
Normal cognitive function
Positive family history of similar symptoms at a similar age
column17: A 2-year-old boy presents with a 6-month history of progressive loss of motor milestones, including sitting and walking independently. He has also developed increasing spasticity, rigidity, and seizures. On examination, he has a cherry-red spot on his macula and mild corneal clouding. His developmental delay is significant, with no speech and minimal response to his environment. He has difficulty swallowing and frequent oral secretions. The patient's condition continues to deteriorate despite supportive care, including physical therapy and anticonvulsant medication. Genetic testing reveals a deficiency in beta-galactosidase activity, confirming the diagnosis of type 1 GM1 gangliosidosis. The family is counseled regarding the poor prognosis and the possibility of rapid disease progression, with life expectancy typically less than three years.
column24: A 27-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with a 5-year history of progressive difficulty with walking, speaking, and swallowing. She has been experiencing increasingly frequent falls and has developed a resting tremor in her hands. Her speech is slow and slurred, and she has difficulty articulating certain words. She denies any cognitive changes or seizures but reports worsening dystonia that affects her daily activities. On examination, she has a kinetic-rigid syndrome with bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural tremors predominantly in the upper limbs. She also has mild ataxia and decreased reflexes. Her cognitive function is normal. The patient's medical history includes delayed motor development in childhood, and she was diagnosed with GM1 gangliosidosis type III at age 20 years. Family history is unremarkable. Laboratory tests show a markedly reduced beta-galactosidase enzyme level, confirming the diagnosis. Genetic testing reveals a compound heterozygote for the c.193A>C and c.852G>C mutations in the GLB1 gene.

column3:
A 4-year-old boy, John, presents to the endocrinology clinic with short stature and delayed growth. He was born at 37 weeks gestation and had a birth weight of 2.5 kg. His parents are concerned about his slow growth rate and want an evaluation for growth hormone deficiency. On examination, John's height is below the 10th percentile for his age, and he has a small head circumference. He also has mild developmental delay and speech difficulties. Genetic testing reveals a deletion of chromosome 7p11.2, consistent with Silver-Russell syndrome.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
Short stature and delayed growth
Small head circumference
Mild developmental delay and speech difficulties
Deletion of chromosome 7p11.2 (Silver-Russell syndrome)
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of difficulty losing weight despite diet and exercise, fatigue, and cold intolerance. She also mentions that she has had trouble conceiving for the past year. On examination, she is short in stature (4 feet 10 inches) and has a small frame. Her blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, heart rate is 70 beats per minute, and body mass index (BMI) is 35 kg/m2. Laboratory tests reveal elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels and low free thyroxine (FT4) levels, consistent with hypothyroidism. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the DIO2 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Silver-Russell syndrome.
column17: Patient: Emily, a 4-year-old girl, presents to the pediatrician's office for a routine check-up. Her mother mentions that Emily has been having difficulty keeping up with her peers in terms of growth and development. Emily was born at 37 weeks gestation, weighing 2.8 kg (5.9 lbs) and measuring 43 cm (17 inches) in length. Her head circumference at birth was 36 cm (14.2 inches), which was above the 90th percentile for her age and sex. Since then, Emily's growth has been slow, and she is currently below the 5th percentile for both weight and height. She has a prominent forehead, frontal bossing, and a small, triangular face with a pointed chin. Her limbs are asymmetrical, with her left arm being slightly shorter than her right. Emily also has clinodactyly of her fifth fingers. The pediatrician notes that Emily's developmental milestones have been delayed, and she is currently struggling to learn basic motor skills such as dressing and using the bathroom. Emily's mother reports that she has been a picky eater and has had difficulty gaining weight. The pediatrician suspects that Emily may have Silver-Russell
column24: Ms. A is a 35-year-old woman who presents to the clinic with a lifetime history of short stature and growth difficulties. She was born small for gestational age and had a prominent forehead and relative macrocephaly at birth, with a head circumference that was consistently above the 90th percentile. She also had a triangular face, thin lips, large eyes, and bluish sclera. Ms. A's growth trajectory has been below the 3rd percentile throughout her life, and she currently stands at 4 feet 8 inches tall. She has also noticed that her limbs are slightly asymmetrical, with her left arm being shorter than her right. Additionally, Ms. A has had difficulty gaining weight and has very little subcutaneous fat tissue. She has a small chin and a wide mouth with down-turned corners. Ms. A reports that she was slow to learn motor skills as a child and had some difficulties in school, but she is otherwise healthy and intelligent. Based on these clinical features, the Netchine-Harbison Clinical Scoring System (NH-CSS) would likely be used to diagnose Ms. A with Silver-Russell Syndrome.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3:
A 4-year-old boy named Max presents to the pediatrician's office for a routine well-child visit. His mother reports that he has been having some difficulty with fine motor skills, such as buttoning his shirt and tying his shoes. She also mentions that he has been delayed in speech and language development. On examination, Max appears to be a healthy-looking child, but he does have some noticeable physical features, including broad thumbs and halluces, a flat nasal bridge, and a small jaw. He is also noted to have intellectual disability. Genetic testing reveals that Max has Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CREBBP or EP300 genes.
Important clinical features:
* Intellectual disability
* Speech and language delay
* Broad thumbs and halluces
* Flat nasal bridge
* Small jaw
* Genetic mutations (CREBBP or EP300)
column10: A 35-year-old woman with Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up visit. She has a history of intellectual disability, short stature, and facial dysmorphism, including a broad forehead, long face, and small jaw. She also has a congenital heart defect and has had multiple surgeries for this condition. She is currently experiencing some difficulty with fine motor skills and is having trouble with employment due to her cognitive limitations.
column17: Meet Ethan, a bright and curious 4-year-old boy who loves playing with blocks and cars. However, his parents have noticed that he has been having trouble keeping up with other children his age, both physically and cognitively. Ethan was born at full term, but his growth has been slow since the first year of life. He is currently below the 10th percentile for height and weight. His facial features are also distinctive, with downslanted palpebral fissures, a broad and angulated thumb, and a high palate. Ethan has a history of respiratory infections and feeding difficulties, and his parents report that he is a picky eater. He has also been experiencing constipation since infancy. Despite these challenges, Ethan is a happy and friendly child who loves interacting with people. His parents are concerned about his developmental delays and want to explore options for support.
column24: Ms. Smith is a 35-year-old woman with Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome who presents to the clinic for her annual check-up. She has a history of intellectual disability, short stature, and distinctive facial features, including downslanted palpebral fissures, low-hanging columella, and a grimacing smile. She also has talon cusps on her permanent incisors. Ms. Smith has a history of respiratory difficulties and congenital heart defects, for which she has had multiple surgeries. She also experiences joint hypermobility and has a history of keloid formation. Despite these challenges, Ms. Smith is known for her outgoing personality and ability to establish excellent social contacts. However, in recent years, she has experienced sudden mood changes and obsessive-compulsive behavior, which have become more frequent. Her height is 4 feet 8 inches, and her weight is 120 pounds. She has a BMI of 35, which is considered obese. Ms. Smith's IQ is 45, which falls within the average range for individuals with Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome. During the examination, the clinician notices that Ms. Smith has difficulty closing her eyes completely when smiling

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, vomiting, and lethargy. He has a history of developmental delay and seizures. On examination, he is afebrile but has a decreased level of consciousness. His pupils are dilated and unresponsive to light. There is no meningism or focal neurological deficit. Laboratory tests show a WBC count of 18,000/mm3 with 80% polymorphonuclear neutrophils, hemoglobin 7.5 g/dL, platelet count 20,000/mm3, and normal electrolytes and liver enzymes. CSF analysis shows a WBC count of 100/mm3, mostly lymphocytes, protein 40 mg/dL, and glucose 50 mg/dL. CSF culture is negative. MRI scan of the brain shows cerebral edema with effacement of sulci and cortical grooves. EEG shows a burst-suppression pattern. The child is diagnosed with Alpers-Huttenlocher syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by infantile onset of seizures, developmental delay.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with recurrent seizures and confusion. He has a history of progressive cognitive decline, difficulty with coordination and balance, and liver dysfunction. Physical examination reveals a thin, frail man with a vacant expression, poor responsiveness, and difficulty speaking. His liver is enlarged, and he has signs of ascites. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes, low albumin, and coagulopathy. An MRI scan shows cerebral atrophy, and an EEG demonstrates abnormal brain activity consistent with epilepsy. The patient is diagnosed with Alpers-Huttenlocher syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that requires urgent management of seizures, liver disease, and supportive care to prevent further neurological deterioration.
column17: A 4-year-old boy presents to the emergency room with recurrent seizures and loss of consciousness over the past week. The parents report that their child has been experiencing frequent headaches, blurred vision, and difficulty walking for several months. The patient had a normal development until 2 years ago when they started having myoclonic jerks and partial seizures. They have been diagnosed with epilepsy and have been on multiple medications but the seizures have become increasingly intractable. The child is lethargic, irritable, and has difficulty speaking or responding to questions. On examination, they have difficulty walking, poor coordination, and decreased muscle tone. They also have signs of liver dysfunction such as jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes and a viral load consistent with chronic hepatitis B infection. An MRI scan shows cerebral atrophy, white matter degeneration, and prominent sulci. The patient is diagnosed with Alpers-Huttenlocher syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive encephalopathy, intractable epilepsy, and liver disease.
column24: A 28-year-old woman with a history of childhood-onset seizures, cognitive decline, and liver disease presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of her seizures and confusion. She has had recurrent episodes of seizures and liver dysfunction throughout her life, with progressive loss of cognitive function and motor skills. On examination, she is somnolent but arousable, with myoclonic jerks, and irregular breathing patterns. Her liver function tests are elevated, and an abdominal CT scan shows evidence of acute liver failure. The patient's clinical course is complicated by recurrent seizures, respiratory failure, and the need for mechanical ventilation. Despite aggressive management, including liver transplantation, her neurological function continues to decline, and she eventually succumbs to her illness. The most important clinical features in this case include childhood-onset seizures, progressive cognitive decline, liver disease, myoclonus, and respiratory failure.

column3: A 4-year-old boy, named Jack, presents to the clinic with short stature and coarse facial features, including a flat nasal bridge, a prominent forehead, and widely spaced eyes. He also has a history of recurrent respiratory infections and difficulty swallowing. His physical examination reveals joint stiffness and limited range of motion. Jack's developmental milestones have been delayed, and he has difficulty speaking and understanding language. His parents report that he often puts objects in his mouth and has a tendency to drool. The patient's medical history includes a diagnosis of Mucopolysaccharidosis type 2 (MPS II), a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme iduronate-2-sulfatase, which leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans in various tissues, including the brain, bones, and joints.
column10:
A 36-year-old male presents to the clinic with short stature, corneal clouding, and joint stiffness. He was diagnosed with Mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) type 2 as a child and has been receiving enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) for several years. Despite this treatment, he has developed progressive joint damage and reduced mobility in his hands and feet. His corneal clouding has also worsened over time, causing visual impairment. The patient is concerned about the progression of his disease and the potential need for surgical interventions.

Important clinical features:

* Short stature
* Corneal clouding
* Joint stiffness and damage
* Reduced mobility in hands and feet
* History of MPS type 2 diagnosis
* History of ERT treatment
* Progressive disease despite treatment
* Concerns about surgical interventions.
column17: Patient: Jackson Age: 3 years Gender: Male\n\nJackson is a 3-year-old boy who was referred to our clinic due to concerns about his developmental delay and unusual physical features. He was born at term and had a normal delivery, but his parents noticed that he wasn't meeting his milestones on time. They also noticed that his head seemed larger than usual, and his face looked different. Jackson has been experiencing frequent ear infections and respiratory tract infections since he was 18 months old. He also has a hoarse voice and has difficulty articulating words. Physical examination revealed a large head, macroglossia, and coarsened facial features. His height and weight were below the 5th percentile for his age. Jackson's developmental assessment showed significant delays in speech, language, and gross motor skills. He also had mild cognitive impairment. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis of Mucopolysaccharidosis type II (MPS II), a genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce certain enzymes needed for the breakdown and recycling of sugar molecules. Jackson's parents were counseled about the condition, and they were referred to a multidisciplinary team of specialists who will work together to manage his symptoms
column24: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and recurrent respiratory tract infections over the past year. He also reports difficulty swallowing and a hoarse voice. On examination, he has a large head, prominent forehead, and an enlarged tongue. His height is 4 feet 8 inches, and he has a large abdomen with a protruding belly button. He has limited mobility in his hands and wrists due to stiff joints. The patient's hearing is impaired, and he has a history of ear infections. His facial features include thickened lips and nostrils. The patient's voice is hoarse, and he has difficulty articulating words. He has a history of umbilical and inguinal hernias repaired in childhood. Family history reveals that the patient's mother had two brothers who died in their teenage years from a similar condition. The patient's development was normal until age 3, when he started experiencing delayed speech and cognitive development. He attended special education classes and has been working in a sheltered workshop. His intelligence is normal. The patient has a history of frequent respiratory tract infections, otitis media, intractable diarrhea

column3: A 3-year-old boy named Jack presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother due to concerns about his developmental delay and limb abnormalities. The patient has difficulty walking independently, and his hands are in a "claw-like" position. He also has a heart murmur. His mother reports that he has had frequent respiratory infections since infancy. Family history is significant for a similar condition in an older sibling who passed away at a young age.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the cardiology clinic with a history of progressive fatigue, dyspnea, and palpitations. He has a long history of heart disease, having been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation 10 years ago. He also has a history of upper limb weakness and was recently diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome. On examination, his blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, pulse rate 110 bpm, respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rhythm with an early systolic murmur at the second left intercostal space. There is also evidence of mild peripheral neuropathy. The patient's fingers are cold to touch, and there is a mild tremor noted in his hands.
column17: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office for a routine check-up. His mother mentions that he has always had difficulty using his right arm and has never been able to straighten his thumb. On examination, the child is noted to have a shortened right arm with a prominent curvature of the thumb and index finger. The child also has a heart murmur and an irregular heart rhythm. Further evaluation reveals a ventricular septal defect and atrial septal defect, as well as abnormalities in the development of the carpal bones in both wrists. The child is diagnosed with Holt-Oram syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the upper limbs and cardiac structures. The most important clinical features of this case include the shortened right arm, curved thumb and index finger, heart murmur, irregular heart rhythm, ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, and abnormal carpal bone development.
column24: A 35-year-old man presents to the cardiology clinic for a routine follow-up appointment. He was diagnosed with Holt-Oram syndrome at birth and has been closely monitored for his entire life. The patient reports no symptoms of chest pain or shortness of breath, but he mentions that he has been experiencing some fatigue and dizziness over the past few months. On physical examination, the patient's vital signs are normal, with a heart rate of 60 beats per minute and blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. The patient's upper limbs show evidence of radial hypoplasia, with a prominent radius on the left arm and a smaller, deformed radius on the right arm. The patient also has a triphalangeal thumb on the left hand and a absent thumb on the right hand. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm with a grade II/VI systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a prolonged PR interval, consistent with first-degree atrioventricular block. The patient is referred for an echocardiogram to evaluate the severity of his cardiac conduction disease and to assess for any structural heart abnormalities.

column3: Meet Emily, a 4-year-old girl who presents to the clinic with her parents due to concerns about her growth and development. She was born at term and had a normal birth weight, but her parents have noticed that she is significantly shorter than her peers and has difficulty walking due to bowed legs. Emily also has distinctive facial features, including a prominent forehead, long eyelashes, and a small jaw. On examination, the clinician notes that Emily's arms and legs are short in comparison to her trunk, and she has limited mobility in her elbows and knees due to joint deformities. Radiographs reveal evidence of rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata, including characteristic "dripping" of the epiphyses and metaphyses of the long bones. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis.
column10: Meet Sarah, a 30-year-old woman with RCDP. She stands at only 4 feet tall and has a distinctive appearance with a small head, short arms and legs, and joint deformities in her hands and feet. Despite her physical limitations, Sarah is an active and independent individual who works as a graphic designer. She has a witty personality and enjoys spending time with friends and family. Sarah's respiratory system is affected, and she often experiences shortness of breath, especially during strenuous activities. She also has some vision and hearing loss but has learned to adapt and uses assistive devices to help her navigate daily life. Despite these challenges, Sarah remains positive and determined to live a fulfilling life.
column17: A 3-month-old male infant was brought to the emergency department due to concerns of slowed growth and developmental delays. The baby was born at full term with a birth weight of 2.8 kg (50th percentile) and length of 47 cm (25th percentile). His head circumference was 32 cm (10th percentile). Since birth, the baby had difficulty feeding and experienced respiratory distress, which worsened over time. Physical examination revealed short limbs, particularly in the humerus, with a rhizomelic pattern. There were also punctate calcifications in the cartilage, epiphyseal and metaphyseal abnormalities, and coronal clefts in the vertebrae. The baby had severe intellectual disability and developed seizures shortly after birth. His cataracts were noticed at 2 months of age. The patient was diagnosed with Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata type 1 (RCDP1), a peroxisome biogenesis disorder (PBD). Further genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis, and the family was counseled on the severity of the condition and the poor prognosis.
column24: A 35-year-old woman with a known history of rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata type 1 (RCDP1) presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up appointment. She was born with cataracts and joint contractures, and her growth and development were significantly delayed. Despite undergoing surgery to correct her joint contractures, she has always had limited mobility and has relied on assistive devices to walk. She has also experienced recurrent seizures throughout her life, for which she takes medication. The patient's height is 130 cm, and her weight is 45 kg. On examination, her limbs are shortened, particularly her humeri, and she has a characteristic "hitchhiker's thumb" deformity. Her vertebrae show coronal clefts, and there are punctate calcifications in her cartilage. The patient's intellectual disability is mild to moderate, and she has difficulty communicating and performing daily tasks independently. Despite these challenges, she is cheerful and friendly and expresses a strong desire to work and participate in activities that interest her.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3:
A 3-year-old boy named Max presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, vomiting, and lethargy. His parents report that he has been having trouble walking and standing, and they noticed that his eyes are shaking (nystagmus). Max was previously healthy, but was recently diagnosed with Sandhoff disease, a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A. On examination, Max has a temperature of 102°F (39°C), and his pupils are dilated and unresponsive to light. He has difficulty standing and walking, and his gait is ataxic. His speech is slurred, and he has difficulty swallowing. The most important clinical features for Max's condition include:
Fever
Vomiting
Lethargy
Nystagmus
Ataxia
Dilated pupils
Slurred speech
Swallowing difficulties
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening headache, nausea, and vomiting. He also reports difficulty speaking and swallowing. On examination, he has a temperature of 101.3°F (38.5°C), blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg, and tachycardia. His speech is slurred, and he has difficulty walking due to ataxia. He has a history of infantile neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis (INCL) and has been diagnosed with Sandhoff disease.
The most important clinical features for this patient include:
• Ataxia
• Slurred speech
• Difficulty swallowing
• Seizures
• Elevated temperature
• Tachycardia
• History of INCL and Sandhoff disease
column17: Patient: A 10-month-old boy who was previously healthy and developmentally normal, now presents with a 2-month history of progressive weakness, slowing of developmental progress, and loss of milestones. He has recently developed seizures, and his parents report that he is not able to sit or stand without support. The child's physical examination reveals hypotonia, poor muscle tone, and a cherry-red macular spot on fundoscopy.
column24: A 35-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with a 2-year history of progressive weakness in his legs, which has recently extended to his arms. He also reports difficulty with balance and coordination, causing him to fall frequently. He experiences fatigue and muscle cramps, especially in his lower limbs. On examination, he has proximal muscle weakness, atrophy, and fasciculations, as well as a broad-based gait with frequent stumbling. His cognitive function is intact. The patient's history and physical examination findings are consistent with a diagnosis of adult-onset Sandhoff disease. Important clinical features include progressive weakness and atrophy of the limbs, cerebellar ataxia, and preserved cognition. Genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis.

column3: A 3-month-old infant, John, is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to concerns of lethargy and poor feeding. The baby was born at term and had a normal delivery. His parents mention that he has been vomiting after almost every feed and seems very sleepy. On examination, John's vital signs are within normal limits, but he appears pale and has a weak cry. His abdomen is soft, with no visible distension or organomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal a serum ammonia level of 1200 μmol/L (normal range: 15-70 μmol/L).
column10: A 27-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening confusion, disorientation, and lethargy. He has a history of Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) and has been non-compliant with his diet and medication regimen. On examination, he has a strong odor of maple syrup emanating from his sweat and urine. His blood work reveals an elevated leucine level. He is admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and treatment of his MSUD crisis.
column17: A 10-day-old male infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to increasing lethargy, poor feeding, and strange movements of his limbs. The baby was born at home without any complications and has been breastfed since birth. On examination, the child appears tired and sleepy but can be aroused with difficulty. He is afebrile, and his vital signs are normal. There is a faint maple syrup odor in his cerumen and urine. Reflexive fencing movements of his limbs are noted. The child is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for close monitoring, and laboratory tests reveal elevated concentrations of branched-chain amino acids and alloisoleucine in his blood. The diagnosis of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is confirmed by genetic testing, and the child is started on a strict diet that limits leucine intake. Parents are educated about the importance of adherence to the diet to prevent recurrent metabolic intoxication and encephalopathy. The most important clinical features in this case include poor feeding, lethargy, strange movements (fencing and bicycling), and maple syrup odor in cerumen and urine, which are all hallmarks of MSUD.
column24: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has a history of intermittent MSUD and has been noncompliant with her thiamine supplements for the past year. On examination, she is lethargic and disoriented, with a temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F) and a blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg. She has a strong maple syrup odor emanating from her body, particularly in her urine. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated concentration of branched-chain amino acids and alloisoleucine in her blood, as well as ketosis. The patient is diagnosed with acute decompensation of MSUD and is immediately started on intravenous thiamine supplements. She responds quickly to treatment and her symptoms resolve within 24 hours. The most important clinical features in this case are the presence of a strong maple syrup odor, elevated concentrations of branched-chain amino acids and alloisoleucine in the blood, ketosis, and the patient's history of intermittent MSUD and noncompliance with thiamine supplements.

column3:
A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a mass in his neck that has been growing over the past few months. He also has a history of recurrent respiratory infections and difficulty swallowing. On examination, the patient has a large, firm mass in the right side of his neck that is tender to palpation. His airway is patent, but he has signs of respiratory distress. The patient's past medical history reveals a diagnosis of infantile myofibromatosis, a rare genetic disorder characterized by multiple benign tumors in the soft tissues of the body.
The most important clinical features for this scenario are:

* Large, firm neck mass
* Tender swelling in the right side of the neck
* Respiratory distress
* History of recurrent respiratory infections
* Diagnosis of infantile myofibromatosis.
column10:
Patient: A 27-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of a slowly growing mass in his right thigh. He has no significant medical history and denies any recent trauma or injuries. The patient is otherwise healthy, with no complaints of pain or discomfort.
Clinical features: On physical examination, there is a 5 cm x 4 cm firm, non-tender mass in the right thigh, located approximately 10 cm below the inguinal ligament. The mass is mobile and moves freely under the skin. There is no overlying skin changes or discoloration. The patient has full range of motion in his right leg and no neurological deficits.
Imaging studies: An MRI scan shows a well-circumscribed, homogeneous mass with low signal intensity on T1-weighted images and high signal intensity on T2-weighted images, consistent with a myofibroma. No evidence of bone involvement
column17: Patient: A 10-month-old baby girl presents to the pediatrician's office with a firm, painless mass on her left cheek that has been growing in size over the past month. The mass is flesh-colored and slightly purple, and the patient's parents report that it has not changed in color or texture. The patient is otherwise healthy and active, with no other symptoms or concerns. Physical examination reveals a solitary nodule on the left cheek, measuring approximately 2 cm in diameter, with no signs of inflammation or ulceration. There are no other abnormalities noted on the skin or in the muscles, and the patient's vital signs are normal.
column24: Patient: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a slowly growing mass on her left shoulder that has been present for several months. She also reports some mild discomfort in the affected area, especially when she moves her arm. The patient has no history of previous cancer or other medical conditions. Physical examination reveals a firm, painless nodule about 3 cm in diameter on the left shoulder, with normal overlying skin. There are no signs of metastasis or other abnormalities.

column3: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with a history of pallor, fatigue, and recurrent infections. On examination, he has a low-grade fever, tachycardia, and mild jaundice. His complete blood count shows anemia, reticulocytopenia, and thrombocytopenia. The patient's medical history reveals that he was born prematurely at 32 weeks' gestation and has been developmentally delayed. Family history is unremarkable. Further diagnostic testing, including a bone marrow aspirate and genetic analysis, confirms the diagnosis of Diamond-Blackfan anemia.
column10: A 27-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician's office, complaining of fatigue and shortness of breath. She has a history of intermittent anemia and has required multiple blood transfusions over the past few years. Physical examination reveals a pale, thin woman with a low-grade fever. Her complete blood count shows a hemoglobin level of 6 g/dL, reticulocyte count of 1%, and a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 70 fL. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, which reveals increased erythropoiesis with abnormal maturation and increased iron stores. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Diamond-Blackfan anemia.
column17: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents due to concerns of pallor and difficulty feeding. The child has been experiencing progressive weakness and fatigue, especially during feeding or while sucking. Physical examination reveals a pale, thin infant with short stature and mild craniofacial anomalies, including a small jaw and upturned nose. There is no organomegaly, signs suggestive of hemolysis, or involvement of other hematopoietic cell lines. Laboratory tests show a profound normochromic and macrocytic anemia with normal leukocytes and platelets. The child's complete blood count (CBC) shows a red blood cell (RBC) count of 2.5 million cells/mm3, hemoglobin (Hb) level of 7 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 120 femtoliters (fL), and mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) level of 30 picograms (pg). The reticulocyte count is low. A bone marrow aspirate and biopsy are performed, revealing a hypoplastic bone marrow with erythroid precursors showing increased apoptosis.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician's office, reporting shortness of breath and fatigue that has worsened over the past year. She also mentions a history of easy bruising and petechiae on her arms and legs. The patient was diagnosed with Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) as an infant and had been managed with blood transfusions and folic acid supplements throughout childhood. On examination, the patient appears pale and has a low body mass index (BMI). Her complete blood count (CBC) shows a normochromic and macrocytic anemia with a hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 120 fL, and red blood cell distribution width (RDW) of 16%. The patient's reticulocyte count is low at 1.5%. A bone marrow biopsy shows erythroid hypoplasia with increased apoptosis. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the RPS19 gene, consistent with DBA. The patient is referred to a hematologist for further management and monitoring.

column3: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents due to a recent diagnosis of Fanconi anemia. The patient has a history of recurrent infections, easy bruising and bleeding, and physical abnormalities such as short stature, microcephaly, and bilateral cryptorchidism. Family history reveals a similar condition in a maternal cousin. Physical examination shows petechiae on the skin, and laboratory tests confirm the presence of Fanconi anemia.
column10:
A 35-year-old woman, G.S., presents to the hematology clinic with a history of recurrent infections and easy bruising. She has had several episodes of pneumonia over the past year, and her family history reveals that she has two siblings who died from acute myeloid leukemia (AML) at young ages. Physical examination shows multiple bruises on her arms and legs, and her complete blood count (CBC) shows a low white blood cell count (WBC), hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL, and platelet count of 50,000/μL. Further diagnostic testing reveals a Fanconi anemia genetic mutation.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
Recurrent infections
Easy bruising
Family history of AML in siblings
Low WBC count
Low platelet count
Fanconi anemia genetic mutation
column17: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with a history of easy bruising and petechiae on his legs. On physical examination, he has short stature, low birth weight, microcephaly, and bilateral limb anomalies (clubfoot and missing patella). The patient also has café-au-lait spots on his skin and hypoplastic thenar eminence. Family history reveals a similar condition in an older sibling who passed away at the age of 10 due to complications from bone marrow failure. The patient's blood work shows thrombocytopenia, macrocytosis, and low white blood cell count. A diagnosis of Fanconi anemia is suspected, and further genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The patient is referred to a hematologist for close monitoring and management of bone marrow failure and potential malignancies.
column24: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a history of fatigue, easy bruising, and recurrent nosebleeds over the past year. He also reports a history of short stature, microcephaly, and bilateral limb malformations. Physical examination reveals petechiae, purpura, and a macrocytic anemia. A complete blood count shows thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and anemia. The patient is referred to a hematologist for further evaluation, and a bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Fanconi anemia. Genetic testing identifies a mutation in the FANCD2 gene. The patient is counseled about his increased risk for malignancy and started on regular cancer screening. He is also referred to a fertility specialist due to concerns about his reproductive health.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the endocrinology clinic with his mother due to concerns about his growth and development. He was diagnosed with Wolfram syndrome at the age of 5, and since then, he has been experiencing progressive vision loss, hearing loss, and difficulty with balance and coordination. He also complains of fatigue, weight loss, and decreased libido. His mother reports that he has had recurrent episodes of pneumonia and bronchitis over the past year.
