The patient is diagnosed with Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome based on clinical features and genetic testing.

column3:
A 4-year-old boy, named Jack, presents to the clinic with short stature and stiff joints. He has difficulty walking due to pain in his knees and ankles. His physical examination reveals coarse facial features, including a flat nasal bridge, a prominent forehead, and widely spaced eyes. He also has a large head, short neck, and a protruding abdomen. Jack's developmental history is significant for delayed milestones, including sitting, standing, and walking. His speech is also delayed, and he has difficulty articulating words. The patient's medical history reveals that he was diagnosed with Mucopolysaccharidosis type 7 (MPS VII) shortly after birth, and he has been receiving weekly enzyme replacement therapy since then. Despite this treatment, Jack continues to experience progressive joint stiffness and pain, which limits his mobility and affects his quality of life.

The most important clinical features in this scenario are:

* Short stature
* Stiff joints
* Coarse facial features (e.g., flat nasal bridge, prominent forehead, widely spaced eyes)
* Large head, short neck, and protruding abdomen
* Delayed developmental milestones (sitting, standing, walking)
column10:
A 36-year-old male presents to the clinic with short stature, corneal clouding, and joint stiffness. He was diagnosed with Mucopolysaccharidosis type 7 (MPS VII) as a child and has been receiving enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) for several years. Despite this treatment, he has developed progressive joint damage and reduced mobility in his hands and feet. His corneal clouding has also worsened over time, causing vision problems. The patient is concerned about the progression of his disease and wants to explore other treatment options.

Important clinical features:

* Short stature
* Corneal clouding
* Joint stiffness and damage
* Reduced mobility in hands and feet
* History of MPS VII diagnosis and ERT treatment
* Progressive disease despite ERT
* Vision problems due to corneal clouding
column17:
Patient: John Smith, Age: 4

Chief Complaint: Difficulty walking and shortness of breath

History of Present Illness: John is a 4-year-old boy who has been experiencing progressive difficulty walking and shortness of breath over the past year. He was previously able to run and play without any issues, but now struggles to keep up with his peers. His parents have also noticed that he has been using his hands to push himself up when standing from a seated position, which they report is a new development. John has also been experiencing frequent respiratory infections, which have been treated with antibiotics. He has not had any surgeries or hospitalizations in the past. 

Past Medical History: John was born at 37 weeks gestation via cesarean section due to fetal distress. His birth weight was 2.8 kg (5.9 lbs). He had a history of neonatal jaundice and was admitted to the NICU for phototherapy. There is no family history of similar symptoms or medical conditions. 

Social History: John lives with his parents and two older siblings. His father works as an engineer, and his mother is a homemaker.
column24:
Patient: John, a 35-year-old male
Chief Complaint: Difficulty walking due to increasing lower back pain and stiffness over the past year.
History of Present Illness: John has been experiencing gradually worsening lower back pain and stiffness for the past year, which has made it difficult for him to walk and perform daily activities. He has also noticed some shortness of breath and fatigue. John has a history of mild intellectual disability and has been followed by a developmental pediatrician since childhood.
Past Medical History: Mucopolysaccharidosis type 7 (MPS VII) was diagnosed in childhood, and he has been receiving enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) every week since age 5. He has also had several surgical interventions for joint contractures and spinal deformities.
Family History: John's older sister also has MPS VII and has similar symptoms. Their parents are carriers.
Social History: John lives with his parents and works part-time in a sheltered workshop. He enjoys playing video games and watching movies.
Review of Systems: Musculoskeletal: John has a history of joint contractures and spinal deformities, which have been managed with surgery and physical therapy. He currently experiences lower back pain

column3:
A 2-year-old boy, John, presents to the pediatrician's office with a 6-month history of progressive weakness and loss of motor skills. He was previously able to sit up and walk independently, but now requires assistance with both activities. John also experiences frequent falls and has difficulty swallowing, leading to frequent pneumonias. On examination, John has a weak cry, poor muscle tone, and diminished reflexes. His parents report that he has lost weight and has had difficulty eating due to weakness of the muscles used for chewing and swallowing.
The most important clinical features in this scenario are:
* Progressive weakness and loss of motor skills
* Difficulty swallowing and frequent pneumonias
* Weak cry and poor muscle tone
* Diminished reflexes
* Loss of weight and difficulty eating.
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with progressive weakness and wasting of muscles in his arms and legs over the past year. He has a history of falls and difficulty walking, and has recently noticed difficulty swallowing and breathing. He has no family history of similar symptoms. Examination reveals marked muscle atrophy, particularly in the proximal muscles of the limbs, and a positive Babinski sign. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of proximal spinal muscular atrophy (PSMA).
The most important clinical features for this patient with PSMA include:
* Progressive weakness and wasting of muscles in the arms and legs
* Difficulty walking, swallowing, and breathing
* Marked muscle atrophy, particularly in the proximal muscles of the limbs
* Positive Babinski sign
* Confirmation of diagnosis by genetic testing.
column17: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the emergency room because of sudden weakness and inability to walk. The parents report that he was previously healthy, but yesterday he woke up with a weak cry and was unable to sit or stand. He has been irritable and vomiting after feeds. On examination, the child is lethargic, with pale and cool peripheral extremities. There is no neck stiffness or meningism. Muscle tone is decreased, and reflexes are absent in the lower limbs. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. Babinski's sign is positive.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a two-year history of progressive weakness in her legs and feet, which has made it difficult for her to walk or stand for long periods. She also reports frequent constipation and gastroesophageal reflux. On physical examination, she has muscle wasting and weakness in her lower limbs, with a positive Gowers' sign (inability to rise from a squatting position without using her hands). Her reflexes are absent, and there is no sensory loss. The patient's medical history includes a previous diagnosis of proximal spinal muscular atrophy type 4 (SMA4), which was confirmed by genetic testing. The most important clinical features in this case are the progressive muscle weakness, muscle wasting, and positive Gowers' sign, which are all consistent with SMA4. Additionally, the patient's history of constipation and gastroesophageal reflux may indicate the need for further management and supportive care.

column3:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after suddenly collapsing during soccer practice. He was unresponsive for a few seconds but quickly regained consciousness. He has no history of seizures or previous episodes. Physical examination shows a normal heart rate and blood pressure, but his electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals coved-type ST segment elevation in leads V1 to V3, consistent with Brugada syndrome.
The most important clinical features for this patient are:
* Sudden collapse during physical activity
* Previous episodes of sudden death in the family
* Abnormal ECG findings (coved-type ST segment elevation)
* No history of seizures or other neurological symptoms.
column10:
A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after suddenly collapsing at work. He has a history of syncope and has been diagnosed with epilepsy, but he has never had a seizure. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows coved-type ST segment elevation in leads V1 to V3, and his echocardiogram reveals a normal left ventricular function and no evidence of thrombus or vegetation. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the SCN5A gene, which codes for the cardiac sodium channel alpha subunit. The patient is diagnosed with Brugada syndrome.
The most important clinical features of this case are:
1. Sudden collapse
2. History of syncope
3. Abnormal ECG showing coved-type ST segment elevation in leads V1 to V3
4. Normal left ventricular function on echocardiogram
5. Positive genetic test for SCN5A mutation
6. Diagnosis of Brugada syndrome
column17: A 6-year-old boy presents to the emergency room after experiencing a sudden loss of consciousness while playing at school. The child had been previously healthy, and there is no family history of cardiac disease. On examination, the patient is alert and stable, with normal vital signs. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rhythm without any murmurs or extra sounds. An ECG shows a coved-type ST segment elevation in leads V1-V3, consistent with Brugada syndrome. The child is immediately referred to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation and management.
column24: Patient: A 35-year-old male who presents to the emergency department after experiencing a sudden episode of syncope while at rest. He has no history of previous cardiac problems and is otherwise healthy. On physical examination, his blood pressure is normal, but he appears pale and diaphoretic. An ECG reveals a Type 1 Brugada pattern with ST segment elevation in leads V1-V3. The patient is immediately referred to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management.

column1: Classic congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21- hydroxylase deficiency
column3:
Patient: John, a 6-year-old boy
Chief Complaint: My son has been feeling tired and weak all the time, and his teacher said he's been having trouble paying attention in class.
History of Present Illness: John was born at term without any notable prenatal or perinatal complications. His parents are non-consanguineous and healthy. He has been well until 6 months ago, when his parents noticed that he was more fatigued than usual and had difficulty paying attention in school. Over the past month, John has also had several episodes of vomiting after eating, with no evidence of gastrointestinal bleeding or infection. There is no history of seizures, loss of consciousness, or developmental delays.
Past Medical History: None
Family History: No consanguinity; both parents are healthy.
Social History: John lives with his biological parents and two younger siblings. He attends public school and has an uneventful preschool history. There is no exposure to toxins, and the family eats a balanced diet.
Review of Systems: No fever, chills, night sweats, or recent weight loss. No changes in appetite, sleep patterns, or respiratory symptoms.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 2-month history of fatigue, weakness, and difficulty concentrating. She also reports a recent weight loss of 10 pounds. The patient has no significant medical history. Physical examination reveals a pale appearance, but is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory tests show a hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL, MCV of 70 fl, and a serum ferritin level of 12 ng/mL.
column17: A 4-day-old female newborn is brought to the emergency room by her parents because of poor feeding, lethargy and dehydration. Physical examination shows a large clitoris, fused labia, and a prominent pseudoscrotum containing a small, undescended testis. The child appears to have a mixture of both male and female genitalia. She is also noted to have a significant amount of hair on her face, arms, and back. The child is admitted for management of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. Further laboratory studies reveal elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels and low cortisol levels. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of classic congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The child is started on glucocorticoid replacement therapy, and her genitalia are surgically corrected at a later age.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with concerns of irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, and acne. She reports that she has had a history of accelerated growth velocity since childhood and has been diagnosed with premature puberty. She also mentions that she has had recurrent episodes of dehydration and hypoglycemia in the past. Physical examination reveals a tall, obese woman with a hirsute appearance, acne on her face and chest, and irregular menstrual cycles. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone and low levels of aldosterone. The patient is diagnosed with classic congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, and treatment with glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids is initiated. The most important clinical features in this case are accelerated growth velocity, premature puberty, hirsutism, acne, dehydration, hypoglycemia, and elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone.

column3: A 7-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office with her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's growth rate. The girl has been growing at a steady rate, but her mother noticed that her hair has been thinning and she has been feeling tired more easily lately. On examination, the patient's vital signs are normal, but her thyroid gland is enlarged and firm to the touch. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of T4 and T3, and a diagnosis of familial thyroid dyshormonogenesis is made.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a complaint of fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance over the past year. She also reports hair loss and dry skin. On examination, she has a slightly enlarged thyroid gland with a firm consistency. Her TSH level is 10 mIU/L, free T4 is 0.8 ng/dL, and free T3 is 25 ng/dL. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the TPO gene consistent with Familial thyroid dyshormonogenesis.
column17: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician's office by her parents due to concerns about her slowed growth and development. She was born at term, and her birth weight was appropriate for gestational age, but she has not been gaining weight as expected. On examination, her head circumference is measuring below the 10th percentile, and she has a prominent tongue and a hoarse cry. The girl also has dry skin and a decreased muscle tone. Her parents mention that they have noticed some swelling in her neck recently. The patient's thyroid function test shows decreased levels of T4 and T3, and an ultrasound of the thyroid gland reveals a nodular goiter. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of familial thyroid dyshormonogenesis.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a several year history of fatigue, weight gain, dry skin, and constipation. She also reports having had a goiter since childhood. On examination, she has a large firm thyroid gland with nodules. Laboratory tests show a T4 level of 20 ng/dL (normal range 50-120 ng/dL) and a TSH level of 10 mU/mL (normal range 0.3-5.0 mU/mL). She is diagnosed with familial thyroid dyshormonogenesis and started on levothyroxine replacement therapy. Over the next several months, her symptoms improve and her goiter decreases in size.

column1: Hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies
column3:
A 10-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of worsening weakness and numbness in his right leg, which has now spread to his left leg. He denies any recent illness or injury but mentions that he has been feeling increasingly tired over the past month. On examination, there is decreased muscle tone and strength in both legs, more pronounced on the right side. There are no areas of sensory loss or weakness in the arms. The patient's reflexes are normal, but his gait is unsteady. Family history reveals that his mother has a similar condition.
Important clinical features:
1. Gradual onset of bilateral lower extremity weakness and numbness
2. No obvious cause (e.g., injury or infection)
3. Progression over days to weeks
4. Presence of fatigue
5. Positive family history of similar condition
6. Normal reflexes
7. Unsteady gait
8. No sensory loss or weakness in the arms.
column10:
A 35-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of numbness and weakness in his hands and feet that started when he was a teenager. He has a family history of similar symptoms in his father and grandfather. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick in the hands and feet, and mild muscle weakness. His reflexes are diminished, and there is no evidence of atrophy or fasciculations. He has a normal EMG and nerve conduction studies. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the PMP22 gene, consistent with hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies (HNPP).
The most important clinical features of this case are:
* Recurrent episodes of numbness and weakness in the hands and feet
* Family history of similar symptoms
* Decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick in the hands and feet
* Mild muscle weakness
* Normal EMG and nerve conduction studies
* Genetic testing revealing a mutation in the PMP22 gene.
column17: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of weakness and numbness in his right hand and foot. He had been playing soccer earlier that day and noticed the symptoms after a fall onto his right side. The patient has a history of similar episodes in the past, which have resolved on their own within a few days. Physical examination reveals weakness in the right hand and foot, with diminished reflexes and sensation in the affected areas. The patient's medical history is significant for Hereditary Neuropathy with Liability to Pressure Palsies (HNPP), a rare genetic disorder that affects the nerves and causes recurrent mononeuropathies. The patient's father has a similar condition, and the family history suggests an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. The patient is admitted for observation and management of his symptoms, and genetic testing is recommended to confirm the diagnosis.
column24: Patient: 35-year-old male presents with sudden onset of foot drop and numbness in his right leg, which started after a strenuous game of soccer. He also reports feeling fatigued and experiencing diffuse pain all over his body. On examination, he has weakness in his right peroneal muscles and decreased sensation on the lateral aspect of his right hand. His deep tendon reflexes are absent. Family history reveals that his mother and maternal grandfather had similar symptoms at a young age.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the pediatric dermatology clinic with a several year history of thickened skin on his palms and soles. The skin is rough and has a sandpapery texture. He also has small, hard bumps on his knuckles and wrists. His parents report that he has had difficulty with fine motor activities such as writing and buttoning shirts due to the thickness of his skin. Examination reveals diffuse palmoplantar keratoderma, Bothnian type, with a distinctive cobblestone appearance on the palms and soles. The patient has no other medical conditions or family history of similar skin issues.
column10:
A 35-year-old male presents with a 10-year history of thickened skin on his palms and soles that has gradually worsened over time. The skin is dry, rough, and cracked, with fissures and erosions, especially in the winter months. He also notices that his skin has become increasingly yellowish in color. The patient has a family history of similar skin changes in his father and grandfather. Examination reveals diffuse palmoplantar keratoderma, with thickened skin on the palms and soles, as well as yellowish discoloration. There is also mild atrophy of the skin, particularly on the fingertips. The patient has a Bothnian type of diffuse palmoplantar keratoderma.
The most important clinical features for this scenario are:
1. Thickened skin on the palms and soles
2. Yellowish discoloration of the skin
3. Dry, rough, and cracked skin with fissures and erosions
4. Family history of similar skin changes
5. Bothnian type of diffuse palmoplantar keratoderma.
column17: A 3-year-old boy presents to the pediatric dermatology clinic with a history of thickened skin on his hands and feet that has been present since birth. The skin appears brown-to-yellowish in color with an erythematous margin, and there is extension to the dorsal aspects of his hands and feet. His parents report that the skin takes on a white, spongy appearance when exposed to water. The child experiences excessive sweating, particularly on his palms and soles. He has had recurrent superinfections with fungal infections. On examination, there are no other skin lesions or abnormalities, and his hair, teeth, and nails appear normal. A skin biopsy is performed to rule out other potential diagnoses, and histological analysis reveals orthohyperkeratosis without epidermolysis. The patient is diagnosed with diffuse palmoplantar keratoderma, Bothnian type. The most important clinical features include the characteristic brown-to-yellowish skin coloration, extension to dorsal aspects of hands and feet, white spongy appearance with water exposure, hyperhidrosis, superinfections, and histological analysis revealing orthohyperkeratosis without epidermolysis.
column24: A 35-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with a lifelong history of thick, yellowish skin on his palms and soles. He reports that his skin has always been this way, and it has never caused him any discomfort. However, he has noticed that his skin tends to become dry and cracked in the winter months, and he often develops small cuts and scrapes on his hands and feet. He also mentions that his sweat glands seem to be overactive, as his skin is always moist and sweaty, especially on his palms and soles. On examination, the patient has diffuse, homogeneous, mild to thick, brown-to-yellowish palmoplantar hyperkeratosis, with extension to the dorsal aspects of his fingers and toes. There is no evidence of epidermolysis or skin fragility. The patient's hair, teeth, and nails appear normal. No other organ systems are involved. Skin biopsy shows non-epidermolytic changes consistent with diffuse palmoplantar keratoderma, Bothnian type.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of weakness in his legs and difficulty speaking. He has a history of progressive muscle weakness over the past year, which has resulted in frequent falls. He also experiences intermittent episodes of double vision and difficulty swallowing. The patient's medical history is significant for Kearns-Sayre syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system. On examination, he has weakness in his limbs, particularly in his legs, and has difficulty walking. His speech is slurred, and he experiences difficulty swallowing. His vision is blurry, and he reports seeing double. The patient's reflexes are diminished, and there is no evidence of muscle wasting or atrophy.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with a 2-year history of progressive weakness and paralysis, mainly affecting her lower limbs. She also reports blurred vision, difficulty speaking, and recurrent headaches. On examination, she has a wide, ataxic gait, poor muscle tone, and decreased reflexes in her legs. Her visual acuity is reduced, and she has difficulty articulating words. The patient's MRI scan shows a large cerebral hemispheric lesion, and genetic testing reveals a mutation in the mtDNA gene.
column17: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 2-year history of progressive weakness and paralysis of the extraocular muscles, resulting in droopy eyelids (ptosis) and difficulty moving his eyes. He also reports gradual loss of hearing and vision, as well as difficulty walking due to unsteadiness and lack of coordination. The patient has a history of delayed puberty and has recently developed heart block, requiring the implantation of a pacemaker. His physical examination reveals bilateral sensorineural deafness, pigmentary retinitis, cerebellar ataxia, dysarthria, and bilateral facial weakness. The patient's intellectual function is mildly impaired. Laboratory tests show an increased lactate/pyruvate ratio in the cerebrospinal fluid, and genetic testing reveals a mutation in the SURF1 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Kearns-Sayre syndrome. The patient is referred for further management and follow-up with a multidisciplinary team of specialists, including neurology, ophthalmology, audiology, cardiology, and endocrinology.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a long history of progressive weakness and vision loss. She was diagnosed with Pearson syndrome as a child, and has since developed bilateral sensorineural deafness, heart block, and cerebellar ataxia. Over the past year, she has noticed worsening difficulty with walking and speaking, and has recently experienced episodes of confusion and disorientation. On examination, she is found to have ptosis, pigmentary retinopathy, and bilateral facial weakness. She also has a slow and irregular heartbeat, and her reflexes are diminished. The patient's cognitive function is impaired, and she has difficulty with memory and concentration. A diagnosis of Kearns-Sayre syndrome is suspected, and genetic testing is recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with difficulty walking and running, muscle weakness, and frequent falls over the past year. He also reports difficulty swallowing and has had a recent decline in his academic performance. On physical examination, he has muscle wasting and weakness in his arms and legs, particularly in the proximal muscles. His deep tendon reflexes are increased, and he has a positive Gower's sign (inability to rise from a squat). The patient's medical history reveals that his mother and maternal grandfather had similar symptoms at a young age.
column10: A 45-year-old man presents to the neurologist's office with complaints of muscle stiffness and weakness in his arms and legs that has been gradually worsening over the past few years. He also reports difficulty swallowing and frequent falls. On examination, he has a characteristic "hunched" posture, with wasted muscles and visible muscle fasciculations. His gait is unsteady, and he has difficulty rising from a seated position. Muscle strength testing reveals a proximal myotonic pattern of weakness. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of proximal myotonic myopathy (PROMM).
column17: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 2-year history of progressive muscle weakness and stiffness, primarily affecting his neck flexors and hip flexors. He experiences frequent muscle cramps and spasms, especially after physical activity, which can be painful and debilitating. The boy has difficulty running, jumping, and climbing stairs, and often feels fatigued. His parents report that he has had difficulty swallowing and has experienced constipation for the past year. The patient's medical history is unremarkable, and there is no family history of similar symptoms. On examination, the boy has proximal muscle weakness, with brisk reflexes and mild muscle atrophy. His gait is unsteady, and he has difficulty standing up from a seated position. The patient's cognitive function appears normal. Laboratory tests reveal elevated creatine kinase levels, and genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of proximal myotonic myopathy (DM2).
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 10-year history of progressive muscle weakness and stiffness, particularly in her neck, shoulders, and hips. She experiences frequent muscle cramps and spasms, especially during physical activity or in cold temperatures. The patient also reports difficulty swallowing and breathing, as well as intermittent abdominal pain. On examination, she has proximal muscle weakness, with a marked decrease in muscle mass and strength in her upper arms and legs. Her reflexes are brisk, and she exhibits myotonia, with delayed relaxation of her muscles after contraction. The patient's medical history includes cataracts and insulin-insensitive type 2 diabetes mellitus. Family history reveals that her mother and maternal grandfather had similar symptoms. The patient is diagnosed with proximal myotonic myopathy (DM2), a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CNBP gene, which codes for a protein involved in muscle function regulation.

column3: A 4-year-old boy named Max presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother due to concerns about his genitalia. Max was born at home with the assistance of a midwife, and his mother had not noticed any issues until recently. Upon examination, the provider notes that Max has a small penis, undescended testes, and a blind-ending vaginal pouch. The patient is otherwise healthy and developmentally appropriate.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a complaint of worsening vision in both eyes over the past year. She also reports experiencing difficulty with balance and walking, as well as frequent falls. On physical examination, the patient has a distinctive facial appearance, including a flat nasal bridge, a small jaw, and widely spaced eyes. Her visual acuity is 20/400 in both eyes, and she has a significant loss of peripheral vision. Funduscopic examination reveals bilateral optic atrophy. The patient's gait is unsteady, and she has difficulty walking heel-to-toe.
column17: A 3-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother, who is concerned about her son's delayed speech and difficulty with urination. The boy was born at 37 weeks gestation via cesarean section due to fetal distress. He had a low birth weight and required oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation in the neonatal intensive care unit for several days. On physical exam, the patient has cryptophthalmos of the left eye, syndactyly of both hands and feet, and ambiguous genitalia. The patient also has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and frequent nighttime awakening to urinate. The mother reports that her son's speech is limited to a few words and sounds, and he often points to objects instead of naming them. Further evaluation reveals a diagnosis of Fraser syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by eye, urinary tract, and genital anomalies, as well as cognitive delays and speech difficulties. The patient is referred for further testing and management, including genetic counseling and speech therapy.
column24: A 35-year-old male presents to the urology clinic with a history of urinary retention and recurrent urinary tract infections. He was born with ambiguous genitalia, and his parents had chosen not to pursue gender assignment surgery at the time. On physical examination, he has syndactyly of both hands and feet, and his genitalia are underdeveloped. Imaging studies reveal bilateral cryptophthalmos and renal agenesis. He is scheduled for further evaluation by a multidisciplinary team to address his urogenital anomalies and determine the best course of treatment.

column3:
A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after falling and hitting his head on the edge of the coffee table. He has a history of easy bruising and bleeding gums. His parents report that he has had several nosebleeds in the past year, and they have noticed small red spots on his skin that seem to appear out of nowhere. The patient is pale and has a low-grade fever. On examination, there are multiple ecchymoses (larger bruises) on his arms and legs, and his gums are bleeding. The patient's vital signs are normal except for a low blood pressure.
The most important clinical features of this scenario include:
Easy bruising
Bleeding gums
Nosebleeds
Small red spots on the skin (petechiae)
Pale appearance
Low-grade fever
Multiple ecchymoses on the arms and legs.
column10:
A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset left knee pain and swelling after twisting his knee while playing soccer. He has a history of congenital fibrinogen deficiency, for which he receives regular infusions of fibrinogen concentrate. His last infusion was 2 weeks ago. Physical examination reveals a swollen and tender left knee with limited range of motion. There is no evidence of an overt bleed, but the patient reports mild bruising around the knee. The patient's blood work shows a low level of fibrinogen, and he is diagnosed with a fibrinogen deficiency-related joint bleed.

The most important clinical features in this scenario are:

1. Sudden onset knee pain and swelling
2. Limited range of motion
3. Mild bruising around the knee
4. Low level of fibrinogen on blood work
5. History of congenital fibrinogen deficiency and regular infusions of fibrinogen concentrate.
column17:
Patient: A 4-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a history of recurrent nosebleeds and bruising following minor trauma. He was born at term, and his birth weight was appropriate for gestational age. There is no family history of bleeding disorders. On examination, the patient has petechiae on his arms and legs, and his blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Laboratory tests show a reduced level of fibrinogen in his blood. The patient is diagnosed with congenital fibrinogen deficiency (hypofibrinogenemia).

The most important clinical features of this patient's presentation are: 

1. Recurrent nosebleeds and bruising following minor trauma, indicating a bleeding disorder. 
2. Absence of family history of bleeding disorders, suggesting a spontaneous mutation or novel inheritance pattern. 
3. Low blood pressure (80/50 mmHg), which may indicate hypovolemia due to recurrent bleeding episodes. 
4. Reduced level of fibrinogen in the blood, confirming the diagnosis of congenital fibrinogen deficiency (hypofibrinogenemia).
column24:
Patient: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of nosebleeds and bruising following a minor fall. He has a history of recurrent nosebleeds, easy bruising, and prolonged bleeding after dental extractions. Family history reveals a maternal grandfather who died from intracranial hemorrhage at the age of 40. Physical examination shows petechiae, ecchymoses, and swelling of the right knee. Laboratory tests show a reduced level of fibrinogen (150 mg/dL) and normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT. The patient is diagnosed with congenital fibrinogen deficiency (hypofibrinogenemia).

The most important clinical features in this vignette are: 

1. Family history of a bleeding disorder in a first-degree relative (maternal grandfather).
2. Recurrent nosebleeds and easy bruising, which suggest a lifelong bleeding tendency.
3. Prolonged bleeding after dental extractions, indicating a postsurgical bleeding risk.
4. Low fibrinogen levels (150 mg/dL)

column1: Tumor necrosis factor receptor 1 associated periodic syndrome
column3:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with fever, abdominal pain, and vomiting. He has had recurrent episodes of fever and abdominal pain over the past year, which have been increasing in frequency and severity. The patient's family history is significant for autoimmune diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, with no other notable findings. Laboratory studies show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP), as well as a positive test for Tumor necrosis factor receptor 1 (TNFR1) gene mutation. The patient is diagnosed with TNFR1-associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS).
The most important clinical features of this scenario are:
Recurrent episodes of fever and abdominal pain
Family history of autoimmune diseases
Positive test for TNFR1 gene mutation
Elevated ESR and CRP.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with recurrent episodes of fever, chills, and joint pain over the past year. She has also noticed that her skin has become thin and fragile, with easy bruising. Physical examination reveals a maculopapular rash on her arms and legs. Laboratory tests show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP), indicating inflammation. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the TNFRSF1A gene, confirming the diagnosis of Tumor necrosis factor receptor 1 associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS). The patient is referred to a rheumatologist for further management.
column17:
Patient: A 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of fever, abdominal pain, and skin rash. She has had similar episodes in the past, but they have become more frequent and severe over time. On examination, she has tender swelling of her knees and ankles, conjunctivitis, and a macular rash on her arms and legs. Her blood work shows elevated inflammatory markers and mild anemia. She is diagnosed with Tumor necrosis factor receptor 1 associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS).

Most important clinical features:

* Recurrent fever and abdominal pain
* Skin rash (erythema, edematous plaques, urticarial lesions)
* Eye involvement (conjunctivitis, periorbital edema)
* Serosal inflammation (pleuritis, peritonitis)
* Arthralgias and myalgia
* Increased risk of secondary amyloidosis and atherosclerosis.
column24: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, chills, and severe joint pain. She also reports experiencing recurrent episodes of similar symptoms over the past year, which have been increasing in frequency and severity. On physical examination, she has tender swelling of her knees and ankles, conjunctivitis, and a macular rash on her arms and legs. Her blood work shows elevated inflammatory markers and mild anemia. She is diagnosed with Tumor necrosis factor receptor 1 associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS) based on her clinical features and genetic testing, which reveals a mutation in the TNFRSF1A gene. The patient is started on corticosteroids to control her symptoms and prevent further amyloidosis deposition.
